docs.title: About CadenzaFlow?Enterprise Grade, long-term and open-source Workflow Platform
docs.text:
CadenzaFlow is a secure, enterprise-grade Workflow Management product by PiA. In response to Camunda's recent strategic shift - including the discontinuation of support for Camunda 7 Community Edition and renounce of some key principles - it is a modern, stable fork of Camunda 7 with a robust Enterprise grade roadmap fully supported and maintained by PiA commited to retain the best features and to-be discountinued open source freedom of Camunda.

  • ✅ Truly open-source Community Edition - no hidden licensing restrictions for production use, aligning with what our customers expect.
  • ✅ Optional Enterprise Edition - available for organizations requiring advanced features and support.
  • ✅ Long-Term Support (LTS) and maintenance - actively maintained for both Community and Enterprise Editions.
  • ✅ Uncompromising operational manageability - built-in capabilities for robust process governance and observability.
  • ✅ AI-powered and agentic orchestration features - coming soon to enhance automation and decision-making.
  • ✅ Enterprise-grade human task management - streamlined, scalable, and built for real-world workflows.
  • ✅ Full backward compatibility - ensuring seamless migration paths from Camunda 7.

docs.title: Enterprise Workflow Management (EWfM) Manifesto
docs.text:
In the rapidly evolving landscape of workflow automation, navigating the so critical ecosystem of so-called BPM engines and libraries can be deceptively complex. While many claim compliance with open standards like BPMN, they often conceal architectural pitfalls - from being tightly embedded within application runtimes to lacking essential operational controls: a clear No-Go for the Enterprise grade workflow platform user.

Some others claim scalability, but at the cost of operational manageability; others promise standards, but fail to deliver enterprise-grade autonomy and manageability.

As PiA, to avoid these traps for all our customer base and also out flagship products like DNext, we ground our strategy in a clear, principled Enterprise Workflow Management (EWfM) Manifesto:

EWfM Manifesto

  1. External, Not Embedded - and Truly BPMN-Compliant We commit to Workflow Engines that are: external, decoupled, and can serve front-end/back-end centric. Workflow logic must be externally modeled, executed, governed and operationally managed - never entangled with internal application components or back-end services.
  2. Enterprise-Grade and Open Source - No Trade-Offs Enterprise capabilities should never come at the cost of openness. We insist on open-source engines to ensure transparency, extensibility, and long-term control - vendor lock-in is not an option.
  3. MACH-Aligned and Event-Driven by Design We align with MACH principles: Microservices, API-first, Cloud-native, Headless. Workflow task triggering must be asynchronous and event-driven, integrating seamlessly with distributed microservice ecosystems.
  4. Operational Manageability Is Non-Negotiable Rich operational APIs for process control, observability, intervention, and SLA enforcement are essential. We reject any engine that sacrifices operational transparency for theoretical scalability.

To that end, we are proud to announce our decision to maintain and further develop our own dedicated branch of the Camunda engine called "CadenzaFlow", just like how Camunda was born as a branch of Activiti which preferred to shine on embedded, developer centric capabilities compromising Enterprise Grade capabilities.

This move reaffirms our commitment to open, external, enterprise-grade workflow orchestration - and ensures that our customers remain aligned with a future-proof, transparent, and operationally robust process automation platform.

docs.title: Why CadenzaFlow?
docs.text:
Originated as a fork of Activiti 5.10 in early 2013, with a focus on enterprise-grade stability, better BPMN compliance, and stronger operational tooling, Camunda 7—while inheriting the original principles of being open source - has become a key player in the Enterprise Workflow Management (EWfM) market, with a significant number of organizations relying on it for mission-critical process orchestration.

For institutions that rely on the reliability, BPMN 2.0 compliance, integration flexibility of Camunda 7 as well as its operational manageability features, the upcoming end of support for Camunda 7 Community Edition in 2025 challenges many organizations with difficult decisions.

After the release of the final version (v7.24) in October of 2025, development of the system will be stopped by Camunda and the repositories will be archived and marked as deprecated.

Facts

Fact-1: This means that there will be no future updates or security patches, which poses a significant risk to the stability and security of your enterprise organization's business processes.

Fact-2: After October 2025 - putting aside all other lack of operational manageability issues of Camunda 8 - Enterprise organizations utilizing Camunda 7 Community Edition in development/test and production environments are caught between a rock and a hard place.

  • If they switch to Camunda 8, since it is NOT fully open-source form production, they end-up with huge unexpected costs;
  • Even if they choose to bear the cost, depending on the as-is usage of Camunda 7, a huge refactoring on existing source code based may be enforced.
  • Even if they choose to bear the cost, still due to lack of many operational manageability features (suspend processes, skip tasks etc.) on Camunda 8, a huge refactoring on existing workflow definitions may bee needed as well as operational side effects, plus as-is operational UIs utilizing Camunda 7 operational APIs.

Fact-3: Simply stated, Camunda 7 better at operational manageability, weaker at scale. Camunda 8 better at scale, but weaker at control. For an enterprise: Power and Scale without control is chaos and history is full of such distributed sytem failures.

In response to Camunda's recent strategic shift - including the discontinuation of support for Camunda 7 Community Edition and a Camunda 8 roadmap that departs from core principles of open source and enterprise-grade operational manageability - many PiA customers now face uncertainty in sustaining their workflow foundations. These changes directly challenge the values embedded in our Enterprise Workflow Management (EWfM) Manifesto.

To that end, we are proud to announce our decision to maintain and further develop our own product "CadenzaFlow" - a dedicated branch of the Camunda 7 engine. This move reaffirms our commitment to open, external, enterprise-grade workflow orchestration - and ensures that our customers remain aligned with a future-proof, transparent, and operationally robust process automation platform.

By doing so:

  • As PiA Group we provide long-term strategic assurance to PiA customers who rely on robust, external BPM engines as a foundational layer of their IT ecosystems.
  • For our flagship products, such as DNext, this path ensures continuity, stability, and alignment with the architectural expectations of modern digital business support systems (DBSS).
  • More importantly, this move safeguards the open-source, enterprise-grade capabilities that our customers as well as our products - ensuring that customers retain both freedom and control without compromising on scale, governance, or operational depth.

Please refer to White Paper: Camunda 8 Architecture: Enterprise-Grade Critique for details.

docs.title: 1. Terms and Definitions
docs.text:
The following table provides a glossary of terms and definitions used in this library:

Definition Description Billing Tariff (a.k.a Billing Price Plan) An integrated context of schedule and/or scheme and/or formulas used by Billing processes for aggregation/classification/collation of financial artifacts, such as; bill line items, GL allocation items, tax items, cost center allocation items etc. Charge The actual demanded/calculated Price (please refer to definition for Price) for a sales item; services rendered or hard/soft goods supplied, considering aspects other than the set Tariff price. Actual charge of the same thing being sold to different buyers, may be different compared to the regular Price set on a Tariff, as Charge typically will consider other price alterations, discounts and business rules applied specific to the buyer. Charging Tariff (a.k.a Charging Price Plan) An integrated context of schedule and/or scheme and/or formulas used by Charging processes used for Price calculation of a sales items. Customization or Customer Adaptation Refers to a customer adaptation for the purpose of integrating or adapting out-of-the-box provided product components and/or APIs. Such customization examples(including, but not limited to) are: add-on software packages as task/protocol adapters, file import/export utilities, custom specific process/workflow configurations etc. Configuration Indicates any configurational change to control functional and/or non-functional aspects of the system or one of its components. The change may be (including, but not limited to) via updating of information that may reside in files, relational/non-relation databases, key-value store updates over distributed configuration management service APIs, etc. Discount A reduction/value alteration made on Price that impacts (depending on application time) the Charge and/or billed item amount. Discounts may be:
  • Simple Discounts; 10% discount on the list price.
  • Friends/Family Discounts; served party defines/declares a limited set of destination addresses via a relevant product offering, and transaction discounted if destination address is a member of this set.
  • Community Discounts; Discount applied as part of tariff rules that check if both served and other party subject to transaction belong to a community group.
  • Free Units or Aggregation based Discounts; Free up to 4GB of usage, or 50% discount after 300 minutes of international call.
  • Complex cross-discounts; 1GB of free high-speed data connection for every 60min of international call within a bill period.
  • Tiered or percentage based discounts on one or more bill line items based on aggregated charges that apply to a particular bill cycle or financial terms.
Fee A fixed Charge calculated for a service performed by a person/system or as a compensation to cover the cost of a process whether be human-centric or system-controlled, such as; consulting fee, late payment fee etc. Monetization Monetization refers to standards and processes defined/adopted for deriving revenue from the value you offer to your customers. Price (a.k.a List Price) The amount of money expected to be paid or set as consideration (typically on a Tariff/Price Plan) for a sales item; services rendered or hard/soft goods supplied. Price Plan (a.k.a Tariff) Please refer to definition for Tariff Promotion An integrated context of schedule and/or scheme and/or formulas used to increase sales, product public awareness. Promotions shall not be confused with Discounts. A promotion may use one or more several tools to increase sales and awareness, such as; loyalty points, bonus points, advertising and discounting. Rate Rate can be considered as a specialization of Price. Thus, Price may always be used interchangeably with Rate. Rate is a defined Price value of a sales item for a specific context according to a ratio, scale, or standard, such as; 0.05$ per minute of domestic phone call, 1$ per minute of international phone call. Tariff (a.k.a Price Plan) An integrated context of schedule and/or scheme and/or formulas used for calculation/aggregation purposes by Charging and Billing processes. Please refer to definitions for: Charging Tariff, Billing Tariff

docs.title: Categories
docs.text:
Important

Please consider the following categories 1-4:

  1. External/BPM Engine - Refers to components required to run CadenzaFlow the SAME as Camunda 7 external BPM engine (including Camunda 7 http-REST API)
  2. Embedded/BPM Engine - Refers to components required to run CadenzaFlow the SAME as embedding the Camunda 7 engine into another Java application
  3. Front-end/UI - Refers to UI components required to run CadenzaFlow the SAME as Camunda 7 UI (Cockpit, Tasklist, Admin, Modeler, etc.)
  4. Client development - Refers to client development components for developing and executing BPMN/DMN tasks that constitute workflows (Java delegates, external tasks, etc.)

Please also note that all releases will be available for download via CadenzaFlow web site and GitHub.

docs.title: Realization of an IoT Platform using TMFORUM compliant DNext Building Blocks
Introduction
docs.text:
"Telecoms is at a crucial turning point. The last decade has dealt a series of punishing blows to an industry that had previously enjoyed enviable growth for more than 20 years. Services that once returned high margins are being reduced to commodities in the digital world, and our insatiable appetite for data demands continuous investment in infrastructure. On the other hand, communications service providers (CSPs) and their partners are in an excellent position to guide and capitalize on the next wave of digital revolution. The growth opportunities attached to new 5G ecosystems are estimated to be worth over $580 billion in the next decade." [^1]

A quick reflection on the history, reveals a stunning fact about pace of business change: ~500years of change is LESS THAN ~50years of change is LESS THAN the last ~20years of change

  • 1500s-1950s: First, Second and Third Industrial Revolutions. Cars, Planes, Television, Cameras and Plain old Telephony in our lives.
  • 1950s-2000s: Start of Fourth Industrial Revolution: Internet Born, Personal Computers, Mobile Phones
  • 2000s-2010s: Second wave of Fourth Industrial Revolution: High Speed Broadband Internet, ECommerce Boom, On-Demand High-Definition Content, 3G/4G Internet and Mobility Everywhere
  • 2010s-NEXT: Next wave of Fourth Industrial Revolution: Cloud Computing, Big Data, Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence based Analytics, Prediction, Internet of Things (IoT) and 5G enabling: Mobile Broadband, Massive Machine to Machine and Ultra Reliable Communication Infrastructure everywhere

Especially the following areas of technology will play a significant role and drive new digital business ecosystems:

  • 5G allowing ground breaking capabilities for next generation apps and services anytime, anywhere providing three types of specialized connectivity: high-throughput broadband access (10Gbps), ultra reliable low latency networks (1ms) and massive machine type communications allowing millions of devices on a small area (1km2)
  • IoT (Internet of Things) technologies allowing many different types of appliances, devices and items connected to the global Internet
  • SDN (Software Defined Networking) / NFV (Network Function Virtualization) / Cloud technologies allowing intent based fully controllable networks, virtual infrastructures that can be dynamically scaled, load-balanced across disperse geographical locations and distributed physical infrastructures; all of which making it possible to dynamically orchestrate, on-the-fly deploy and scale the entire lifecycle of apps and network functions accessible anywhere, anytime
  • Blockchain technology allowing digital contracts (Smart Contracts) revolutionizing both identity and trust management

For the Telecom Operators or CSPs that want to capitalize on IoT business utilizing the advantages made possible through the 5G infrastructure investments, this whitepaper describes a possible revolutionary BSS/OSS (Business and Operational Support Systems) transformation by realizing an IoT Platform via TMFORUM ODA compliant modules of DNext; The Next Generation, Cloud based, Digital Customer Experience Platform by PiA.

docs.title: The Platform and Platform Business
docs.text:
In a nutshell, a platform business is “a business based on enabling value-creating interactions between external producers and consumers. The platform provides an open, participative infrastructure for these interactions and sets governance conditions for them. The platform’s overarching purpose to consummate matches among users and facilitate the exchange of goods, services, or social currency, thereby enabling value creation for all participants.” [^2]

Figure-1: Traditional Pipeline vs Platform Business

Similar to applying a dependency inversion principle for utmost flexibility to software systems, the main idea is to break the linear chain of traditional pipeline and insert in between well defined interfaces implemented by the Platform that facilitate standardized mechanisms for exchange of goods and/or services between multiple producers and consumers.

Thus, similar to Amazon, the Platform Owner (such as Telco Operator) can expose product offerings it doesn't own or produce, can provide inventory, common catalog facilities, as well as omni-channel sales UIs, can vet and measure performances of solution partners, collecting quality and/or KPI data with other metrics resulting in enhanced customer experiences for consumers and faster time-to-market for its partners.

docs.title: IoT Business
docs.text:
The Internet of Things (IoT) describes the network of physical objects “things”—that are embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies for the purpose of connecting and exchanging valuable data with other devices and systems over the internet.

IoT is a perfect business use case enforcing the Platform Business, since from a Telco Operator's perspective, there are many partners at play incorporating and the Operator has to sell products/solutions that it does NOT own or produce. Some of the players (including but not limited to) are; Device Manufacturers, SIM Manufacturers, Network/Connectivity Providers (aka Telco Operators), IoT Application Providers, Logistics/Shipment Providers, Distriubutors etc.

docs.title: IoT Platform realized with Dnext in the Core
docs.text:
Below diagram depicts a conceptual view of the IoT Platform enabled via Dnext components in the core.

  • The Northbound constitutes the set of experience and engagement APIs and processes of the IoT Platform for managing the Customer experience and interactions of the Business Partners to freely onboard their solutions, APIs such as; Onboarding Devices, placing Orders, Searching Product and/or Resource Inventories etc.
  • The Southbound constitutes the set of managed and orchestrated aspects of the IoT Platform for enabling the IoT Solutions, such as; Connectivity, Backing Applications, Devices and Shipment.
  • The Eastbound is the Info Stream flowing from all internal processes, App PLatforms and Devices that make it possible for value-added Intelligence and Analytics
  • The Westbound is the Revenue Stream made possible via the IoT Platform that enables the Operator to capitalize on IoT Offerings of its partners and be able to sell IoT Solutions that it does not directly own or produce
  • Cloud Native, TMFORUM Open API compliant, standardized DNext micro-services constitute the IoT Platform Core Modules that allow seperation of business policies and external interfaces (managed by Adapters) from transactional components of implementation (DNext Modules), resulting in a flexible, easy to maintain and scale low OPEX system.

Thus, One IoT Platform, but means many to many:

  • For the Sales-UI/Market Place => It is Order Management
  • For the IoT Solution/Device Suppliers => It is Inventory Mgmt and SOlution Onboarding
  • For the Logistics/Shipment Partner => It is Procurement/Distribution dispatcher
  • For the IoT Solution backing Application Provider => It is License Management (License Type, Capacity etc.)
  • For the Operator/Platform Owner
  • Product/Service Catalog
  • Resource/Device Catalog
  • Product/Device Inventory
  • Sales and Order Management System
  • Order Fulfillment, Activation/Provisioning System
  • Logistics/Shipment/Just in Time Manufactiring Orchestrator
  • Analytics/Intelligence Platform

docs.title: DNext in the Core of IoT Platform
docs.text:
DNext is the Next Generation, Cloud based, Digital Customer Experience Platform by PiA that conforms the TMFORUM Open APIs and Open Digital Architecture.

Compliant to TMFORUM Open Digital Architecture, DNext Modules are packaged as container images the de facto ready-to run deployment units of modern cloud native applications and expose their capabilities via TMFORUM Open APIs compliant http-REST web services (aka micro-services).

Logically, the modules can be grouped as the following:

  • Systems of Engagement: DNext Modules of this group are mainly Web UI modules that focus on managing experience and interactions. Some examples of DNext Modules utilized for IoT Platform are: Catalog Management UIs, Customer/Account Management UIs
  • Systems of Records: DNext Modules of this group mainly focus on realizing operational processes of real world. This Group can be further logically grouped into three sub groups:
  • Party Management: DNext Modules of this group utilized in IoT Platform focus on managing Party, Party Roles, Customer and Agreement Information.
  • Core Commerce Management: DNext Modules of this group utilized in IoT Platform focus on managing Sales, Product Catalog and Catalog driven Order Fulfillment as well as orchestration of Shipment and Product Inventory Management.
  • Production: DNext Modules of this group utilized in IoT Platform focus on managing the lower levels of ho products are realized, such as Resource Catalog Management, Resource Order Management as well as Resource Inventory Management,
  • Systems of Insights: All Dnext Modules follow a standardized component anatomy, enabling standardized LOGs, metrics, KPIS informations as well as supporting notification and messaging services. Thus, rather than enforcing a single solution, it becomes possible to easily integrate with any Analytics, Log Management and Monitoring system. The result is an IoT Platform that provides insights on business activities, and supports actionable analytics.

The result is an on/off premise custom, yet standardized, cloud-native flexible IoT Platform that can realize the enterprise's business policies as required, meanwhile still benefiting via utilizing on industry standard and proven TMFORUM open API compliant components of PiA's DNext.

[^1]: TMFORUM IG1166 ODA Architecture Vision Rel 18 [^2]: Platform Revolution book by Geoffrey Parker, Marshall Van Alstyne and Sangeet Paul Choudary

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text:
"The success of any business endeavor is ultimately measured in its ability to generate value for the enterprise, either in terms of explicit monetary profit or tangible value which can be translated into monetary profit through a related activity. This is true of a single enterprise or an ecosystem of partners. In the context of ecosystems--a federation of multiple enterprises (e.g. commercial, governmental, charitable, non-profit organizations) – this is further complicated by competing forces and differing priorities of the ecosystem partners, who will each have independent interests outside of the ecosystem. Ref. [1]"

Figure-1: Why Monetization?

We are all on the brink of an unprecedented digital revolution that will dramatically change the way we live, interact and how businesses conducted. For the first time in history, the businesses are being challenged with so many drivers of change from different perspectives: new markets, new technology, new business models, new policies, new demands for scale, security and regulation compliancy. Simply, an evolutionary transformation is not enough, and only the businesses that can succeed in such a revolutionary transformation with their core Business and Operational Support Systems (BSS/OSS) will survive.

A quick reflection on the history, reveals a stunning fact about pace of business change: ~500years of change is LESS THAN ~50years of change is LESS THAN the last ~20years of change

  • 1500s-1950s: First, Second and Third Industrial Revolutions. Cars, Planes, Television, Cameras and Plain old Telephony in our lives.
  • 1950s-2000s: Start of Fourth Industrial Revolution: Internet Born, Personal Computers, Mobile Phones
  • 2000s-2010s: Second wave of Fourth Industrial Revolution: High Speed Broadband Internet, ECommerce Boom, On-Demand High-Definition Content, 3G/4G Internet and Mobility Everywhere
  • 2010s-NEXT: Next wave of Fourth Industrial Revolution: Cloud Computing, Big Data, Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence based Analytics, Prediction, Internet of Things (IoT) and 5G enabling: Mobile Broadband, Massive Machine to Machine and Ultra Reliable Communication Infrastructure everywhere

Especially the following areas of technology will play a significant role and drive new digital business ecosystems:

  • 5G allowing ground breaking capabilities for next generation apps and services anytime, anywhere providing three types of specialized connectivity: high-throughput broadband access (10Gbps), ultra reliable low latency networks (1ms) and massive machine type communications allowing millions of devices on a small area (1km2)
  • IoT (Internet of Things) technologies allowing many different types of appliances, devices and items connected to the global Internet
  • SDN (Software Defined Networking) / NFV (Network Function Virtualization) / Cloud technologies allowing intent based fully controllable networks, virtual infrastructures that can be dynamically scaled, load-balanced across disperse geographical locations and distributed physical infrastructures; all of which making it possible to dynamically orchestrate, on-the-fly deploy and scale the entire lifecycle of apps and network functions accessible anywhere, anytime
  • Blockchain technology allowing digital contracts (Smart Contracts) revolutionizing both identity and trust management

This new digital business ecosystems paradigm is expected to dominate as new offerings are curated, combining products from multiple service providers or from adjacent sectors involving many business partners to create new propositions for customers and leverage value-added up-sell for service providers. These ecosystems will inevitably create greater complexity in managing the commercial relationship within the ecosystem - recognizing that each partner will have their own business processes and systems managing their enterprise.

The following diagram depicts some of the realities of the precedented complexities and its impacts on monetization.

Figure-2: New Digital Business Ecosystems

"The business-to-consumer (B2C) world has been transformed by social media and commerce platforms, enabled by service providers’ multi-billion-dollar investments in global communication networks. However, as mobile data has enjoyed a compound annual growth rate of 66 percent for the last five years, research by Accenture for the World Economic Forum shows that the share of profits going to the owners and operators of these networks has declined from 60 percent a decade ago to 45 percent today. Ubiquitous connectivity has driven down prices, eroded profit margins and lengthened the time it takes for new infrastructure to pay back, which is slowing the innovation cycle. Ref. [2]".

On the business landscape, today's service providers must not only compete with Google, Amazon or Apple, but also must figure out how to transform their as-is business to platform-based ecosystems or how to actively participate on other ecosystems like Amazon's or Google's ecosystems. Plus, with the new business potential driven by 5G and IOT, service providers must also partner and be part of Independent Software Vendor, Automobile, Equipment supplier and alike ecosystems.

On the technology landscape, all businesses want to become operationally more agile and cost effective taking advantage of the new technological advancements such as SDN/NFV combined with a move to Cloud computing. These transformations, meanwhile providing agility and scalability, are changing the fundamental infrastructures of businesses as well as introducing new partners and cost centers to be considered within the monetization processes.

The following diagram depicts the potential market size, target markets and industries, which will impact not only communication service providers, but all business types.

Figure-3: Market Potential

Important

As a consequence, the rise of e-commerce, communication technologies and the advent of the digital economy blended with the new operational models are profoundly changing how businesses think and operate. Today’s B2B and B2C customers expect products and services to be delivered and billed on demand – in minutes, rather than days and weeks. Today's B2B partners expect new multi-party business alliance and partnership models to be modeled and established immediately with relevant offerings to be launched on commercial sales catalog in hours, rather than weeks.

Thus, for the digital service providers that aim to generate new revenue streams, fully modeling, orchestrating and sharing the revenue among business partners, the necessity for a next generation Monetization Platform is inevitable.

The aforementioned mesh of business drivers necessitate: dramatically agile, business flexible, operationally scalable, ready to integrate Monetization Platform for the next generation digital service provider IT systems.

docs.title: What's MonE?
docs.text:
MonE is an on/off-premise cloud native Monetization Platform by PiA. MonE enables transformation from the current state of C/B&RM (Charging, Billing and Revenue Management) systems to future mode of Monetization Platform in which:

  • The current state of C&B represents proliferated and segregated silos of billing systems, either monolithic or old-style layered architectures with standards/processes developed to charge and bill for events generated through physical network elements as well as for events on product/service orders generated via Order Management systems, without any consolidated capabilities for complex pricing, charging methods, partner billing and revenue sharing models.

  • The future mode of Monetization Platform represents a distributed, flexible monetization system comprised of lego-approach service based components. Enabled by MonE, this next generation Monetization Platform considers technology impacts of IoT, 5G, SDN/NFV and Cloud on your business whether be Telecom, Energy, Utility of Medical Billing based, as well as providing capabilities for managing multiple revenue streams, charging, pricing, payment methods and revenue sharing of complex partner ecosystems.

The result is an on/off premise cloud-native flexible model-driven system in which enterprise's business, finance and partner strategies being modeled in MonE Monetization Template Models and MonE Tariff, Discount and Balance/Quota Model Packages; MonE Platform executes these models for managing the converged B2B and B2C charging, billing, settlement and revenue sharing journey of the enterprise.

docs.title: Capability Pillars and Concepts
docs.text:
This section provides a business overview of Capability Pillars that constitute MonE platform and highlights the critical concepts that differentiate MonE. for a further detailed description of features, please refer to sections Functional Features Overview and Nonfunctional Features Overview.

The following diagram depicts the pillars of MonE considering different viewpoints, such as Key Aspects and Unique Digital Experience, Operational Experience and Technology stack.

Figure-1: Capability Pillars of MonE

The following sections provide details related to each viewpoint.

docs.title: 1.1. MonE Monetization Template Models
docs.text:
Definition

Monetization refers to standards and processes defined/adopted for deriving revenue from the value you offer to your customers.

Within an ecosystem, as part of a digital platform based business, a service operator will have many different service offerings. Different service offerings will have their own pricing strategies for different price types (onetime, recurrent, usage etc.) to address different value propositions to the customer. Moreover, pricing and tariff determination must also take into account the values of additional qualifiers such as timestamp, volume, duration, location, channel, cost introduced by involved business partners, infrastructure etc.

MonE Monetization Template Models provide support for the next generation digital business monetization options amid the complex ecosystem of service providers and other involved business partners as the following:

  • Define and execute the strategy for B2C (end customer) with flexible rules for determining involved customers, who pays for what, when, and which charges, how charges are calculated from charging metrics and which tariffs to used that derive pricing methods subject to calculations

  • Define and execute the strategy for B2B (partners) with flexible rules for determining involved partners, revenue sharing rules, who pays or needs to be settled for what, when, and which charges, how charges are calculated from charging metrics contexts and which tariffs or end customer charges to used that derive pricing methods subject to calculations

The following depicts a high-level view of MonE Monetization Template Models, providing insights with regards to the flexibility of the platform.

Figure-2: MonE Monetization Model

docs.title: 1.2. MonE Tariffs
docs.text:
Definition

Tariffs denote an integrated context of schedule and/or scheme and/or formulas used by Charging and Billing processes with built-in conditional rulesets contained.

MonE Platform utilizes two types of tariffs:

  • Charging Tariff (a.k.a Charging Price Plan): An integrated context of schedule and/or scheme and/or formulas used by Charging processes used for Price calculation of a sales items.
  • Billing Tariff (a.k.a Billing Price Plan): An integrated context of schedule and/or scheme and/or formulas used by Billing processes for aggregation/classification/collation of financial artifacts, such as; bill line items, GL allocation items, tax items, cost center allocation items etc.

The following diagram depicts the generic tariff concept whether be for charging or billing.

Figure-3: MonE Tariff Concept

To further illustrate this ultra flexible concept, the following diagram depicts a sample charging tariff concept model.

Figure-4: MonE Usage Tariff Concept

Lastly, MonE tariffs are even at the very low-level business model aligned and what the Service Provider thinks is what is in the physical tariff with the full flexibility of XML, JSON or YAML encoding. The following diagram depicts a JSON encoded preview of the realization of Usage Tariff Concept provided in Figure-4 above.

Figure-5: MonE Usage Tariff in JSON Sample

docs.title: 1.3. Flexible Discount and Promo Models
docs.text:
In addition to next-gen configurable capabilities summarized in Section 1.1 that allows reflecting enterprise strategies onto charging and billing, MonE provides multiple ways of discounting and promotional capabilities.

Definition

Discount refers to a reduction/value alteration made on Price that impacts (depending on application time) the Charge and/or bill line item amount (bill line items constitute the bill or settlement statement).

Promotion refers to an integrated context of schedule and/or scheme and/or formulas used to increase sales, product public awareness. Promotions shall not be confused with Discounts. A promotion may use one or more several tools to increase sales and awareness, such as; loyalty points, bonus points, advertising and discounting.

Thus considering the two main sub domains of MonE being Charging and Billing, out-of-the-box provided discounting and promotional capabilities are as the following:

Application Time Type Name Description Charging Discount Price Alteration An alteration as a fixed amount or percentage on the price. Typically applied for non-usage related charging on one-time and/or recurrent charges related to orders submitted to MonE. Charging Discount Free Units Volume or Monetary based (on defined periods auto reset) quotas that allow free of charge usages. Charging Discount Tiered/Progressive Discounts Volume or Monetary driven one or multiple thresholds based modification/reductions on original charge amount that encourages consumption of a related service or product offering. Charging Discount Cross Discounts Volume or Monetary driven one or multiple thresholds that allows multi-levels of discounting on service offering A, when aggregated usage/purchase of service offering B reaches a certain threshold ranges. Billing Bill Line Item Discounts Bill Line Item based Tiered/Progressive Discounts Volume or Monetary driven one or multiple thresholds that allows multi-levels of discounting on lump sum amount on an bill line item prior to generation of official financial invoice, such as extra 10% discount on invoice amount of offering A, if the usage amount after Charging discounts has exceeded 50$ in the current bill cycle Billing Invoice Discounts Invoice Amount Discounts A reduction in lump sum amount of the invoice irrelevant of the items that constitute the total invoice charge.

docs.title: 1.4. B2C and B2B Convergence
docs.text: As illustrated in Section 1.1, MonE allows a consolidated event driven platform to manage B2C and B2B related charging and billing with the required support for multiple pricing types, charging and billing modes, such as apply usage charge on party-B using the tariff of party-A with a billing mode of in-advance.

docs.title: 1.5. Multiple Operation Modes
docs.text:
MonE provides several plug and play operational modes considering the very different nature of charging and billing domains.

  • Charging: MonE provides the mechanisms and interfaces that allows file based offline charging, event based on-line charging and session based online charging that utilize the same rating and balance management functionality resulting in charged transactions fed into Billing domain

  • Billing: MonE provides the mechanisms and interfaces that allows for an individual account immediate generation of hot bills items, on-demand bills, quotation bills. MonE also supports Batch Bill generation that allows mass generation of consolidated bills for multiple subscriptions that pertain a specific bill cycle term and a market segmentation.

docs.title: 1.6. Decoupled and Integrated Open APIs
docs.text:
MonE comes out of the box with support for the industry leading and widely accepted TMFORUM Open APIs that relate to billing, such as Account Management or ProductOrder APIs. This approach allows not only minimizing the time-to-deploy, but also drastically reduces integration costs of the enterprise organizations that operate on standards compliant business application components, such as Product Catalogue Management and/or Order Management systems.

The following diagram conceptually depicts such a complex order submitted by Order Management for a sample Billing Account-123 that comprises:

  • IP-Telephony (Voice over IP) offering with a price alteration
  • ADSL_BASIC_NET4, Broad Band ADSL Access offering
  • 4GB Free Quota with over usage charging
  • Commitment of 2 years

Figure-6: MonE Product Order Concept

docs.title: 2. Operational Excellence
docs.text:
Cloud native and microservice architectures gain a lot of popularity due to the ever-increasing complexity of systems. Thus, Communication service providers (CSPs) and suppliers are committed to delivering cloud-native, reusable software components, and replacing legacy OSS/BSS to enable industry to transform business agility and unlock growth.

In this regards, once considered as an second degree of importance factor, Operational Excellence now becomes as critical or even more critical than ever. CSPs once focusing on edge case functionalities now prefer a system with enough functional capabilities, but that can scale and comes out-of-the-box with distributed analytical capabilities.

The following diagram depicts key aspects of MonE supported capabilities from Operational Excellence viewpoint.

Figure-7: Operational Excellence

docs.title: 3. Standard Best Of Breed Technology Stack
docs.text: MonE platform targets open source software usage in order to minimize license and other commercials costs. Cloud native and microservice architectures gain a lot of popularity due to the ever-increasing complexity of systems with many alike tools for the vendors to build their products. However, utilizing the right technology for the right purpose is crucial. For further details, please refer to MonE Cloud Native Technology Landscape.

docs.title: 4. Integration and Open APIs
docs.text:
Open Digital Architecture initiative, led by TMFORUM focuses on the principles, guidelines for delivering cloud-native, reusable software components, and replacing legacy OSS/BSS to enable industry to transform business agility and unlock growth. Due to the ever increasing complexity of systems, it becomes more and more critical for a system and all its components to be ready to integrate, communicate via and against industry standard open APIs.

MonE platform components support TMFORUM Open APIs and ready to integrate with 3PP legacy systems via conventional API managers such as WSO2. For a further detailed specification of APIs, please refer to APIs View.

docs.title: 5. Intelligence and Actionable Analytics
docs.text:
Considering the ever increasing complexity and distributed nature of new generation systems, the following elements are the keys to ensure uninterrupted system operation.

  • Reliable Infrastructure with built-in redundancy and no single point of failure
  • Adequate system resources to handle fluctuating processing requirements
  • Resilience & Scalability seamlessly resilient & scalable application architectures and dynamic deployment mechanisms
  • Continuous data collections, periodic processes, audit and monitoring to ensure infrastructure and application elements meet and exceed requirements
  • Diagnosis, detection and prediction of any infrastructure, application or resource issues before they impact system operation with automated actions*

The last two are directly related to the systems capability for Intelligence and Actionable Analytics. In this regards, MonE provides built-in and out-of-the-box capabilities for operational analytics and integration to intelligence systems.

docs.title: Functional Features Overview
docs.text:
This section provides an elaborate product features overview of MonE. To have a 360° understanding of the capability domains that constitute MonE functional landscape, the following diagram illustrates a categorized classification of the main functional domains of Features.

Figure-1: MonE Functional Feature Domains

These main functional domains of features are as the following:

  • Open Integration APIs Features: Public Integration APIs capability set provided by relevant MonE components allow integration of MonE Platform to the Enterprise or Service Provider's BSS (Business Support System) Application stack such as; Customer Management Systems, Order Management Systems etc.

  • Monetization Template Model Features: MonE Monetization Template Models enable modeling the financial business associations of the enterprise considering B2C and B2B financial relations and roles of each party involved. Once configured, the Monetization Template Models drive the processing chain utilizing on capabilities provided by Charging Features and Billing Features domains. In this regards, the features in this domain allow setting model driven strategies and rules that determine (including, but not limited to); who pays for what, when, and which type of charges, how charges are calculated from charging metrics and which tariffs to used that derive pricing methods subject to calculations, what B2B parties involved, revenue sharing rules etc.

  • Charging Features: MonE Charging features cover the capabilities provided by the MonE Charging subsystem, such as: supported charging API types and operational modes, charge event filtering/collation/enrichment/aggregation capabilities, charge amount calculation capabilities (flat, tiered, elastic etc.) and supported metrics (QoS, channel, time, zone), basic discounting capabilities, balance management and complex discounting capabilities (free units, cross discounts etc.)

  • Billing Features: MonE Billing features cover the capabilities provided by the MonE Billing subsystem, such as: supported billing operational modes, classification/aggregation capabilities per different financial perspectives (bill line items, taxation, GL posting etc.), bill time applied discounts capabilities

  • Platform Common Functional Features: MonE Billing features relate to common platform functional features, such as; Event Management, Operational Intelligence and Analytical capabilities etc.

The following sections provide a list of features for each relevant functional domain.

docs.title: 1. Open Integration APIs Features
docs.text:

docs.title: 2. Monetization Template Model Features
docs.text:
Definition

Monetization refers to standards and processes defined/adopted for deriving revenue from the value you offer to your customers as wells as the settlement of incoming/outgoing revenue for the involved B2B partners.

MonE Monetization Template Models refer to a set of configurative conditional contexts that allow the next generation platform business driven Enterprise Organizations or Service Providers to model revenue generation and settlement strategies of different product offerings for B2C and B2B amid the complex ecosystem of service providers and other involved business partners. At the very high level, these MonE Monetization Template Models (MonE MTM) drive the event input, charging, discounting, billing and revenue settlement processing pertaining to specific product offerings.

The following diagram illustrates the constituents of MonE MTMs. At the very high-level, MonE MTMs are comprised of MonE Mediation MTM, Charging MTM and Billing MTM, in which Charging MTM further consists of PreCharging MTM, B2C Charging MTM and B2B Charging MTM.

It shall be noted that meanwhile MonE MTMs drive the main information flows, dictating collation/cloning of input events, determination of involved parties and charges to be generated, the additional components within MonE Charging and Billing takes care of the fine-grained processing of these items considering B2C and/or B2B accounts associated tariffs, assigned products, discounts etc..

Please refer to next sections regarding such features specific to MonE Charging and Billing.

Figure-2: MonE MTM-Monetization Template Model Features

docs.title: 2.1. MonE Mediation MTM
docs.text:
Mediation Templates allow configurable mapping, collation and ingestion of chargeable or billable (pre-charged) events into MonE. A different Mediation MTM can ve configured for each different tuple of (EventInputChannel, FileNamingPattern).

Once configured the following features are provided via Mediation MTMs that allow generic ingestion of any event into MonE whether for charging and/or billing purposes:

  • Event Qualifiers: This generic mapping allows providing configurable event processing hints to MonE, such as setting; Request Type (PriceRequest, TariffRequest), Pricing Type to be applied (onetime, recurrent, usage) etc.
  • DateTime Quantities: This generic mapping allows providing configurable date time events mapping with role specification of each entity to be further considered by MonE Charging/Billing
  • Involved Charging Metric Data and UoMs (Units of Measurement): This generic mapping allows providing configurable metric info mapping (duration, total/uplink/downlink data volume, number of quantities etc.) with role specification of each entity to be further considered by MonE Charging/Billing
  • Involved ResourceAndAddress Identifiers: This generic mapping allows providing configurable address and resource identifier mapping (served_party, other_party, serving element_address, location_address etc.) with role specification of each entity to be further considered by MonE Charging/Billing
  • Involved Service/Prod Identifiers: This generic mapping allows providing configurable service/product identifier mapping with role specification of each entity to be further considered by MonE Charging/Billing

docs.title: 2.2. MonE PreCharging MTM
docs.text:
MonE PreCharging MTMs determine the pre-charging MTM templates to be applied for the specific event type. It shall be noted that only after resolution of the pre-charging model driven criteria, the actual B2C and B2B charging can continue and charging templates can continue to be applied.

Once the PreCharging MTM RuleSet is executed and the PreCharging MTM to be applied is determined for the relevant input event/stream, the PreCharging MTM provides features that allows configurable determination of the following:

  • Normalization: Involved ResourceAndAddress Identifiers to be normalized and the normalization strategy to be applied (reference address etc.)
  • Product Identification: Involved Product roles and identification keys to be applied for each, additional qualifiers, such as a flag indicating whether identification of the item is mandatory for charging to continue etc.
  • Involved B2C Party Accounts: Involved B2C Account roles and identification keys to be applied for each, additional qualifiers, such as a flag indicating whether identification of the item is mandatory for charging to continue etc.
  • Involved B2B Party Accounts: Involved B2B Account roles and identification keys to be applied for each, additional qualifiers, such as a flag indicating whether identification of the item is mandatory for charging to continue etc.

docs.title: 2.3. MonE B2C Charging MTM
docs.text:
MonE B2C Charging MTMs determine the charging MTM templates to be applied for the specific event type. It shall be noted that it is the B2C Charging MTMs that decide how many charges to be created for which of the involved B2C party accounts, using what/whose tariff, applying what charging method etc.

Once the B2C Charging MTM RuleSet is executed and the Charging MTM to be applied is determined, the B2C Charging MTM provides features that allows configurable determination of the following:

  • Determine number of B2C Charge Items (CI) to be created
  • For EACH B2C CI Determine
    • Set chargedAccount
    • Set payerAccount
    • Set Price Type (OT, REC, USG, etc.)
    • Resolve input quantity/metrics
    • Calculate Charge as configured per Monetization Template charging method: Tariff defined in the system, tariff assigned to an involved party account, or tariff submitted as part of order.
    • For tariff based calculations apply the concluded charge method (drives calculation method: flat, percentage, tiered etc.)

docs.title: 2.4. MonE B2B Charging MTM
docs.text:
MonE B2B Charging MTMs determine the charging MTM templates to be applied for the specific event type. It shall be noted that it is the B2B Charging MTMs that decide how many charges to be created for which of the B2B involved party accounts, using what/whose tariff, applying what charging method, whether bill or a settlement note etc.

Once the B2B Charging MTM RuleSet is executed and the Charging MTM to be applied is determined, the B2B Charging MTM provides features that allows configurable determination of the following:

  • Determine number of B2B Charge Items (CI) to be created
  • For EACH B2C CI Determine
    • Set chargedAccount
    • Set payerAccount
    • Set Price Type (OT, REC, USG, etc.)
    • Resolve input quantity/metrics
    • Calculate Charge as configured per Monetization Template charging method: Tariff defined in the system, tariff assigned to an involved party account, or tariff submitted as part of order. For B2B input may be the charge applied to a B2C account.
    • For tariff based calculations apply the concluded charge method (drives calculation method: flat, percentage, tiered etc.)

docs.title: 2.5. MonE Billing MTM
docs.text:
MonE Billing MTMs determine the billing MTM templates to be applied. It shall be noted that it is the Billing MTMs that decide the mechanical aggregation/classification rules that relate to bill line items aggregation, tax items aggregation, GL code aggregation etc.

Once the Billing MTM RuleSet is executed and the Billing MTM to be applied is determined, the Billing MTM provides features that allows configurable determination of the following:

  • For EACH (Payer Acct, Charge Item)
    • Determine Billing MTM to be Applied
    • Determine/override billingAccount as per Split billing rules assigned to account. If no rules, billedAccount=chargedAccount
    • Rules for Bill Line Item Aggregation
    • Rules for Accounting/GL Item Aggregation
    • Rules for Tax/Item Aggregation
    • Rules for External Cost Center Aggregation

docs.title: 2.6. Other Enhanced Features
docs.text:
In addition to many flexible and unique features supported by MonE aforementioned in above sections, the following are (including, but not limited to) some other critical enhanced features that allows a better perception of the value MonE brings into the enterprise business:

  • Elastic/Dynamic Pricing: A pricing where MonE Charging Tariff decision tree dictates a varying rate calculation method as a function of external load demand separate to predetermined factors like location/time/date/usage
ChargeAmount = f(externalSupply, externalDemand)
  • Blended Rate: A billing time applied function that allows overriding the aggregated amount for a specific bill line item. The amount is determined as a function of calculating a weighted average over multiple periods that allows smoothing of outliers.
InvoiceItemAmount = W*Avg(itemX, numberOfPeriods)

  • External Cost Center Allocation: A billing time applied additional classification and aggregation function that can be sold as a value added product allowing classifying charged items based on an explicitly assigned external cost allocation plan. The result is a customer/partner driven cost allocation report pertaining to internal projects codes of the business partner in addition to legal financial invoice.

  • Best Option Plan: A billing time applied value added function that can be sold as a value added product (supported by charging) that allows assigning additional tariffs to a product and parallel charging of items and let billing choose the best option for a particular bill line item while generating the bill.

  • Credit/Cost Control Quotas and Alerts: Configurable rating and billing time applied cost control and alert mechanisms that prevent bill shocks.

  • Enhanced Commitment Plans: Even though from an ordering and sales perspective, commitments in general indicate duration based commitments with a fixed procedure of penalty calculation if breached, MonE enables managing Commitments with considering the following perspectives:

    • Duration based commitments
    • Revenue based commitments as per revenue generated during a defined period (month, quarter, year, billcycle etc.)
    • Flexible Actions on breach: Apply fixed penalty charge, percentage based penalty charge referring to another charge item, reverse benefits gained via related discount product etc.

  • Enhanced Installment Plans: Order submitted with a related installment plan package can be billed as per the configured pay schedule.

  • Flexible Partner Billing/Settlement Methods: Percentage based, Flat, Transactional Tiered, Aggregated Revenue Tiered, Settlement Immediated, Settlement Upon Payment etc.

docs.title: 3. Payment Card Industry (PCI) Account Data
docs.text:
The Order Management service is not intended for storage, transmission or processing of PCI Account Data. To limit the risk of exposure, PCI Account Data should be re-directed, punched out using an iFrame, or other technology which passes the PCI Account Data from the Client's browser directly to the PCI compliant payment provider.

If necessary, the Order Management service will permit PCI Account Data to traverse the network and be processed on server images within the DMZ and Application tier. The PCI Account Data may be processed in memory and forwarded to your payment provider, but is not permitted to be transferred to the database, or written to any file system on any device with the Order Management service.

Order Management will comply, for the duration of the subscription, with the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) for those controls that are managed by the Order Management service. The applicable controls will be documented through a Self-Assessment Questionnaire for Merchants Version D (SAQ D), which contains an Attestation of Compliance (AOC), or through an appropriate reporting method as specified by the PCI DSS.

docs.title: 1. Business Process Framework (eTOM) Overview
docs.text:
TMFORUM Business Process Framework (eTOM) is a comprehensive, industry-agreed, multi-layered view of the key business processes of the Communication Service Provider (CSP) required to run an efficient, effective and agile digital enterprise. All of the Open Digital Framework, including the Business Process Framework, is created and evolved by industry leaders and practitioners in TMFORUM’s member driven collaboration community.

eTOM is a set of Process Elements, which are organized into a hierarchical framework. The Process Elements are activity-based, and the Business Process Framework is thus an activity-based process decomposition model.

At the highest level are the following domains:

  • The Market & Sales Domain
  • The Customer Domain
  • The Product Domain
  • The Service Domain
  • The Resource Domain
  • The Business Partner Domain
  • The Enterprise Domain
  • The Common Domain

Domains (except for Common) are overlaid onto two main process areas:

  • Strategy to Readiness covering planning, capability delivery and lifecycle management
  • Operations covering the core of operational management

The following diagram depicts Business Process Framework (eTOM) L1.

Figure-1: Business Process Framework (eTOM) L1

So, the Business Process Framework is structured in two main process areas: Operations (OPS) and Strategy to Readiness (S2R). Each contains more detailed process components at Level 1, Level 2, etc. as the processes are decomposed.

docs.title: TMFORUM View
docs.text:
For the Telecom Operator/Communication Service Provider clients leveraging the business capabilities provided by MonE, this section provides de detailed classification of MonE supported functionality considering the following viewpoints and relevant standards managed by TMFORUM:

  • MonE and Open APIs

  • MonE and Open Digital Architecture (ODA)

  • MonE and Business Process Framework (eTOM)

  • MonE and Application Framework (TAM)

  • MonE and Information Framework (SID)

docs.title: MonE and Open Digital Architecture (ODA)
docs.text: This section first provides information regarding MonE design and ODA compliancy.

docs.title: 1. TMFORUM (ODA) Open Digital Architecture Overview
docs.text:
TMFORUM (ODA) Open Digital Architecture (Ref. [3]) offers an industry-agreed blueprint and common terminology providing pragmatic transformation paths from monolithic, legacy software solutions, towards scalable, cloud-based platforms that can be orchestrated with artificial intelligence driven analytics.

The following figure depicts the TMFORUM ODA High-Level Functional Architecture. For a high-level overview of ODA and MonE related functionality relevant to an area, please refer to the following sections.

Figure-1: MonE TMFORUM ODA

docs.title: 2. MonE TMFORUM-ODA Compliancy
docs.text: MonE platform components provide BSS capabilities related to Charging, Billing and Revenue Management within TMFORUM ODA Canvas. The following diagram depicts MonE TMFORUM-ODA Compliancy considering eTOM functionality addressed in each ODA functional block within TMFORUM ODA Canvas. Referring to the diagram, the MonE marked related functionality indicate the relevant MonE Charging, Billing and Revenue Management functionality. Please note that this is a logical TMFORUM ODA aligned view. For a more detailed and actual list of MonE Charging, Billing and Integration API components, please refer to MonE L1 Architecture.

docs.title: 3. MonE TMFORUM-ODA Detailed
docs.text: The following sections provide details about TMFORUM-ODA Functional Canvas, the role and responsibility of each functional block as per TMFORUM perspective and its relation to MonE provided functional capabilities.

docs.title: 3.1. Engagement Management
docs.text:
The engagement management components provide digital, graphical user interface experience and omni-channel capabilities. Within TMFORUM ODA, the common features and goals intrinsic to this functional domain can be characterized as the following:

  • Engagement Management domain deals with "Experience" and "Presentment"
  • Manage the presentation (UI-User Interface) layer according to the channel, the device to allow multi and omni-channel user journeys over multiple types of devices.
  • Handle relationship between external and internal actors (people, organizations and things) and the underlying back-end functional blocks.
  • Manage process driven overall experience; customer, user partner journeys, and tailor interactions using contextual information provided from back end components via open APIs.
  • Being a presentation layer, hold no functions (functional Framework) and no operational data
  • Interaction with underlying back-end blocks through standard TMFORUM Open/REST APIs meaning, process APIs and Event driven APIs

As a back-end system of records, MonE does not provide many substantial components in this functional block, except for the configuration Web UIs.

docs.title: 3.2. Party Management
docs.text:
This functional domain is mainly responsible for the management of organizations or individuals that are involved or likely to get involved with the enterprise (aka service provider) via one or more roles, such as partner, customer etc. Within TMFORUM ODA, the common features and goals intrinsic to this functional domain can be characterized as the following:

  • Party Management domain deals with "WHO" & "WHY"
  • Customer Management
  • Billing Account Management
  • Manage parties; Persons and Organizations
  • Party Bill Inquiry Management
  • Party Bill Payments and Receivables Management
  • Manage party roles
  • Manage all party related entity models; customer, account etc.
  • Manage additional related supportive capabilities, such as Document Management, Identity Access Management

MonE Public APIs working in harmony with MonE back-end charging and billing components provide the related Billing and Revenue management capabilities in this domain.

docs.title: 3.3. Core Commerce Management
docs.text:
This functional block is mainly responsible for realizing core commercial business models, sales, order fulfillment, revenue generation and related assurance processes. Within TMFORUM ODA, the common features and goals intrinsic to this functional domain can be characterized as the following:

  • Core Commerce Management deals with "WHAT"
  • Manage Commercial Product Catalog
  • Manage Core Commerce related process orchestration, entity models, create, read, modification and delete functionalities as well as persistence and retrieval of information to and from database management systems, such as Order Capture or Product Inventory
  • Manage Core Commerce related to Billing and Revenue Management: Charge calculation, discounts, bill calculation, revenue recognition, journalization of revenues etc.
  • Manage additional related supportive capabilities, such as Case Management, Agreement Management etc.

MonE Public APIs working in harmony with MonE back-end charging and billing components provide the related Billing and Revenue management capabilities in this domain.

docs.title: 3.4. Production
docs.text:
The scope of the Production block includes the exposure of its service capability definitions and the dynamic run-time decision of how the service(s) supporting Products and Customer will be created, delivered, used, maintained, assured, and repaired. Within TMFORUM ODA, the common features and goals intrinsic to this functional domain can be characterized as the following:

  • Production deals with the activation and realization, meaning "HOW"
  • Manage Technical Catalog: Services, Resources
  • Manage Balances
  • Manage Core Technical Fulfillment/Activation related process orchestration, entity models, create, read, modification and delete functionalities as well as persistence and retrieval of information to and from database management systems, such as Service Orders, Service Inventory

MonE Public APIs working in harmony with MonE back-end charging and billing components provide the related Billing and Revenue management (especially balance management) capabilities in this domain.

docs.title: 3.5. Decoupling and Integration (D&I)
docs.text:
The Decoupling & Integration (D&I) domain is a conceptual block within TMFORUM ODA Architecture about governing and managing separation of functional borders based on well-established "families" of closely interrelated services as well as the integration between them. Where in traditional architectures functional layers are supposed to communicate only with adjacent ones (e.g. BSS with OSS, OSS with Network but not BSS directly with Network). "Decoupling" within MonE ODA compliant architecture emphasizes that ODA Function Blocks are not behaving like layers and tightly coupled together. This ensures that the functional architecture by itself doesn't preclude any combination of services.

In this regards, open APIs provided by MonE components consider the following:

  • Normalized APIs: Catalog of API's - Management of API catalog and documentations.
  • Message Routing: API Routing - Capability to dynamically Route API calls to endpoint are supported by MonE provided open APIs

docs.title: 3.6. Intelligence Management
docs.text:
Even though, MonE is NOT an intelligence or knowledge management platform, MonE components provide out-of-the-box capabilities with Information Streams to feed next generation Knowledge Systems embedded with Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning and Predictive Analytics features.

From an analytical perspective, all MonE platform components emit process, operational and transactional statistic information to Intelligence Management systems making it possible for the service provider to execute appropriate business, process and operational correlations and aggregations that yield a representation of business and operational reality.

For details, please refer to Intelligence and Actionable Analytics.

docs.title: 4. Other Domains
docs.text: For the sake of completeness from an overall end to end enterprise architectural functional blocks perspective, this section provides information with regards to other domains considering Service Provider's ecosystem.

docs.title: 4.1. Business and Enterprise Management
docs.text:
Enterprises need to manage themselves and this domain represents these common functions are quite generic across many industry sectors and are not peculiar to the communication industry and service providers. Some examples of these are:

  • HR/People Management
  • Financial Management
  • Revenue Assurance Management
  • Security management
  • Knowledge Management: Within Knowledge Management the service providers have very specific and challenging needs that directly utilizes on the capabilities and analytical information provided by Intelligence Management.

docs.title: 4.2. API Gateway
docs.text: In real-life scenarios, as-is BSS/OSS ecosystem of service operators will mandate integration between MonE components and one or more legacy systems over proprietary APIs. Thus, pollution of the overall enterprise integration architecture due to such proprietary external dependencies are avoided.

docs.title: 4.3. DevSecOps
docs.text:
A cloud-native next generation platform cannot ignore DevOps. In this regards, MonE lifecycle management and support considers security incorporated DevOps practices. In this regards, the following set of practices and processes are considered considering MonE software development, security validation and IT operational aspects:

  • Software Change and Config Management
  • Continuous Unit Tests
  • Automated Testing
  • Continuous inspection of development artifacts considering vulnerability, security hot-spots viewpoints
  • Automation and Orchestration considering packaging, container build, application lifecycle management and container platform cluster management

docs.title: 4.4. Network and Infrastructure
docs.text:
For the sake of completeness, this domain represents the network and infrastructure resources of the operator. Impacts of network function virtualization, IoT, Edge computing, 5G network slicing has triggered the need for a radical change in the way networks and services are managed and orchestrated. The services and resources controlled by the Production Management domain will be realized on this infrastructure domain.

The pivotal deployment of IOT, 5G (with network slicing) related infrastructure blended with virtualization technologies and Edge computing has triggered the need for a radical change in the way service operators must standardize and manage an orchestrated infrastructure of networks and services. ETSI ZSM group (Zero-touch network and Service Management) is working on enabling zero-touch automation within the Production that is related to Infrastructure Deployment and Operations management.

docs.title: MonE and Open APIs
docs.text: This section first provides information regarding MonE and Open API compliancy. For further detailed information on Open API, please refer to (Ref. [8]).

docs.title: 1. Open API Overview
docs.text:
TMFORUM Open APIs Framework (Open API) is a comprehensive, collaboratively developed suite of standardized 50+ REST-based Open APIs enabling rapid, repeatable, and flexible integration among operations and management systems, making it easier to create, build and operate complex innovative services. In this aspect, Open API is a global initiative to enable end to end seamless connectivity, interoperability and portability across complex ecosystem based services.

The Information Framework (SID) and the Open API program are working in close relationship: the Data Models used in the different APIs of the Open API program take inputs from the SID when it is appropriate. Thus likewise SID, eTOM and TAM of Frameworx, information view of Open API map is also organized in multiple levels.

At the highest level are the following domains where each suite of Open APIs positioned in a domain imply operations on a bounded context of closely coupled business entities as defined in the specification of relevant API:

  • The Market & Sales Domain
  • The Customer Domain
  • The Product Domain
  • The Service Domain
  • The Resource Domain
  • The Business Partner Domain
  • The Enterprise Domain
  • The Common Domain

docs.text: This section first provides SID background information and then details MonE SID compliancy. For further detailed information on SID, please refer to (Ref. [9]).

docs.title: 1. Information Framework (SID) Overview
docs.text:
The Information Framework (SID) is one of the key components of the TMFORUM Frameworx. TMFORUM Frameworx enables CSPs to analyze their business operations against industry processes (eTOM), applications (TAM) and information standards (SID). The Information Framework (SID) comprises a collection of aggregate business entities (ABEs) whose lifecycle is maintained within responsibility of processes and applications in one of the following domains (domains also inline with eTOM and TAM models):

  • The Market & Sales domain
  • The Customer domain
  • The Product domain
  • The Service Domain
  • The Resource Domain
  • The Business Partner domain
  • The Enterprise domain
  • The Common domain

Please note that, even though together with eTOM, SID has started as one of the pillars of TMFORUM Frameworx, the Information Framework (SID) and the Open API program are working in close relationship: the Data Models used in the different APIs of the Open API program take inputs from the SID when it is appropriate. Therefore for further details of entities at API level, please refer to MonE and Open APIs.

docs.title: MonE and Application Framework (TAM)
docs.text: This section first provides TAM background information and then details MonE TAM compliancy. For further detailed information on TAM, please refer to (Ref. [11]).

docs.title: 1. Application Framework (TAM) Overview
docs.text:
The TMFORUM Application Framework (TAM) provides is a comprehensive, industry-agreed, common reference map to navigate the complex ecosystem Enterprise Architecture in the Communication Service Providers (CSPs). Where the Business Process Framework (a.k.a. eTOM) provides a frame of reference for processes and the Frameworx – Application Framework (a.k.a. TAM) provides a frame of reference for telecom applications functionalities.

TAM is a set/map of industry-agreed classified application blocks, which are organized into a hierarchical framework. At the highest level are the following domains:

  • The Market & Sales Domain
  • The Customer Domain
  • The Product Domain
  • The Service Domain
  • The Resource Domain
  • The Business Partner Domain
  • The Enterprise Domain
  • The Common Domain
  • The Integration Domain

Domains (except for Common and Integration) are overlaid onto two main process areas where the relevant application block positioning is clarified:

  • Strategy to Readiness covering planning, capability delivery and lifecycle management
  • Operations (Operations Readiness & Support, Fulfillment, Assurance, Billing&Revenue Management) covering the core of operational management
