docs.title: HTTP Headers
docs.text:
This section provides information with regards to headers as supported by MonE API. In web-based solutions, HTTP headers allow the client and the server to pass additional information with the request or the response. An HTTP header consists of its case-insensitive name followed by a colon ':', then by its value (without line breaks). Leading white space before the value is ignored. Thus, headers can be grouped according to their contexts:

  • General HTTP Headers: Headers applying to both requests and responses but with no relation to the data eventually transmitted in the body.
  • Request HTTP Headers: Headers containing more information about the resource to be fetched or about the client itself. Request HTTP headers are submitted by the client in requests. The superset of such HTTP headers must comply to as specified in [RFC2730], [RFC2731], [RFC2732],[RFC2734],[RFC2735].
  • Response HTTP Header: Headers with additional information about the response, like its location or about the server itself (name and version etc.). Response HTTP Headers are provided by the server in responses. The superset of such HTTP headers must comply to as specified in [RFC2730], [RFC2731], [RFC2732],[RFC2734],[RFC2735].
  • Entity HTTP Headers: Headers containing more information about the body of the entity, like its content length.

The following sub sections provide details for each HTTP Header specific to MonE API.

Attention

As per RFC2616, header information is case-insensitive.

docs.title: 1.1. Cache-Control
docs.text:
The following response Cache-Control Header directives are supported by MonE APIs as per [RFC7234] with 200 ("OK") responses to http GET requests.

  • must-revalidate: This directive indicates that once it has become stale, a cache MUST NOT use the response to satisfy subsequent requests without successful validation on the origin server (MonE Component API). Default: must-revalidate is set
  • max-age: This directive indicates that the response is to be considered stale after its age is greater than the specified number of seconds. Default: 60
  • no-cache: This directive indicates that the response MUST NOT be used to satisfy a subsequent request without successful validation on the origin server (MonE Component API). This allows an origin server to prevent a cache from using it to satisfy a request without contacting it, even by caches that have been configured to send stale responses. Default: non-cache is not set

Example

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json 
Cache-control: max-age=60, must-revalidate

docs.title: 1.2. CorrelationContext
docs.text:
correlationContext is an optional http-Header directive supported by all MonE Public APIs that contains a collection of related properties. Once provided by external API client, correlationContext context is carried into MonE operational LOG streams and also echoed back in response http-Header for all 2xx, 3xx and 4xx responses. Even though not mandatory, providing all the properties of correlationContext is vital; enables correlation of MonE operations to business transactions initiated by external applications/process management platforms; enables enriched analytical capabilities, such as: time profiling, root cause analysis etc. correlationContext http-Header object contains the following properties.

site: All requests to MonE APIs may contain site that may be provided by external API client. site identifier denotes a specific site specific info.

Example:

  • "West-Coast"
  • "Texas"

domain: All requests to MonE APIs may contain domain that may be provided by external API client. domain identifier denotes a specific application domain info.

Example:

  • "Customer Management"
  • "Order Management"

channel: All requests to MonE APIs may contain channel that may be provided by external API client. channel identifier denotes a specific channel info. The channel may be used to indicate a specific business sub market that may be used for correlation purposes.

Example:

  • "Walmart"
  • "Lakers"

source: All requests to MonE APIs shall contain source provided by external API client. source identifier denotes a specific Enterprise Application that issues a series of MonE Public API calls.

Examples:

  • For an Enterprise Application "OrderManagement-AppA", deployed on West Coast, it may be orchestrated (via an API Manager) to issue MonE API calls with source=XYZ-Billing
  • For a Business Management Platform "BPM-A-CustomerCare", it may be orchestrated (via an API Manager) to issue MonE API calls with source=BPM-A-CustomerCare

source is a free format string, such as: OrderManagement-AppA, BPM-A-CustomerCare. If NOT provided, it will be populated as NULL into MonE LOG streams limiting end2end operational analytics capabilities.

sessionId: All requests to MonE APIs shall contain sessionId provided by external API client. sessionId identifier denotes a Business Session of an Enterprise User/Application Account having logged in/accessed an Enterprise Application/Domain that results a series of MonE Public API calls until logout/end of access.

Example:

  • For an Enterprise Application "OrderManagement-AppA", deployed on West Coast, and for Enterprise User "John Doe" having logged in on 2020-10-10 12:30:00 PST until logout on 2020-10-10 17:30:00, it may be orchestrated (via an API Manager) to issue MonE API calls with the same unique sessionId=df592340-ff9a-11ea-adc1-0242ac120002 (sourceId=OrderManagement-AppA)

SessionId can be a free format string; typically compliant to [RFC4122], sessionId is recommended to conform to UUID universally unique identifier as a 128-bit number, such as: df592340-ff9a-11ea-adc1-0242ac120002. If NOT provided, it will be populated as NULL into MonE LOG streams limiting end2end operational analytics capabilities.

interactionId: All requests to MonE APIs shall contain interactionId provided by external API client. interactionId identifier denotes a Business Interaction within a Business Session that results a series of MonE Public API calls all related to the same customer or account.

Example:

  • For an Enterprise Application "OrderManagement-AppA", deployed on West Coast, and for Enterprise User "John Doe" having logged in on 2020-10-10 12:30:00 PST until logout on 2020-10-10 17:30:00, and having served for billingAccount-A, billingAccount-B and again billingAccount-A respectively and each resulting in 3 MonE API calls, it may be orchestrated (via an API Manager) to issue MonE API calls with (sourceId=OrderManagement-AppA, sessionId=df592340-ff9a-11ea-adc1-0242ac120002):
    • interactionId=1111a054-ff9b-11ea-adc1-0242ac120002 for the first set of three MonE API calls related to billingAccount-A
    • interactionId=2222a054-ff9b-11ea-adc1-0242ac120002 for the second set of three MonE API calls related to billingAccount-B
    • interactionId=3333a054-ff9b-11ea-adc1-0242ac120002 for the third set of three MonE API calls related to billingAccount-A
    • etc.

InteractionId can be a free format string; typically compliant to [RFC4122], interactionId is recommended to conform to UUID universally unique identifier as a 128-bit number, such as: 3333a054-ff9b-11ea-adc1-0242ac120002. If NOT provided, it will be populated as NULL into MonE LOG streams limiting end2end operational analytics capabilities.

transactionId: All requests to MonE APIs shall contain transactionId provided by external API client. transactionId identifier denotes an operational unique Transaction Number within a Business Interaction for a MonE Public API call.

TransactionId can be a free format string; typically compliant to [RFC4122], transactionId is recommended to conform to UUID universally unique identifier as a 128-bit number, such as: 788ca97e-56dd-44ad-ae0b-6edbb2759ec6. If NOT provided, a UUID will be generated by MonE and will be echoed back in response http-Header to calling client.

docs.title: 3. Request headers
docs.text:
The following are critical HTTP headers to be provided by the MonE API clients as part of requests.

  • Accept: This header informs the informs the server (MonE component that provides the relevant API) about the media type(s) required and supported by the client. MonE API(s) supported media type is application/json and charset is utf-8. If a media type is specified that is not supported by the server then the response returned by MonE API will be using the default, application/json, i.e. as if no media type was specified in header. Default: application/json; charset=utf-8. Please note that charset directive is optional, default encoding being utf-8.
  • Accept-Language: This header informs the server (MonE component that provides the relevant API) about the human language the server is expected to send back. If a language is specified that is not supported by the server then the response returned by MonE API will be using the default, en_GB, i.e. as if no language type was specified in header. Default: en_GB
  • Authorization: MonE supports API Key based authentication used together with HTTPS for public APIs. An API key is a unique identifier token/secret that a client provides as part of http-REST call parameter when making MonE Public API calls. Authorization is only used in cases of OAuth. In this case, The HTTP Authorization request header contains the credentials to authenticate/authorize API user agent with a server, usually, but not necessarily, after the server has responded with a 401 Unauthorized status and the WWW-Authenticate response header. Authorization header value contains TYPE_space_CREDENTIALS where;
    • TYPE: Indicates authentication method type, such as Basic or Bearer
    • space: space
    • CREDENTIALS: Indicates credentials context required for authentication/authorization depending on type. For details regarding MonE API supported security capabilities, please refer to Protocol Security.

Example

...

Accept: application/json; charset=utf-8
Accept-Language: en_GB

...

docs.title: 4. Response headers
docs.text:
The following are critical HTTP headers to be provided to to client requests in MonE API responses.

  • WWW-Authenticate: The HTTP WWW-Authenticate response header is sent along 401 Unauthorized response and defines the authentication method that should be used to gain access to a resource. WWW-Authenticate header value contains TYPE_space_REALM where;
    • TYPE: Indicates authentication method type, such as Basic, Bearer or OAuth
    • space: space
    • REALM: In the form of "realm=[realm context]" provides a description of protected area. For details regarding MonE API supported security capabilities, please refer to Protocol Security.
  • Location: Typically provided when served with 201 (Created) in response to resource creation, or when served with 3xx (redirection). It provides created resource URL or redirection URL. This is not a guaranteed supported response header by MonE APIs for resource creation. For resource creation responses, instead the reference URL in response payload shall be used by the client.
  • ETag: This header allows caches to be more efficient, and saves bandwidth, as a web server does not need to send a full response if the content has not changed. On the other side, if the content has changed, ETag(s) are useful to help prevent simultaneous updates of a resource from overwriting each other ("mid-air collisions"). If the resource at a given URL changes, a new Etag value must be generated. ETag(s) are therefore similar to fingerprints and might also be used for tracking purposes by some servers. A comparison of them allows to quickly determine whether two representations of a resource are the same, but they might also be set to persist indefinitely by a tracking server.
  • X-Total-Count: Regarding query of Collection Resource types, the response is an array of entities. For query-based pagination, the HTTP header “X-Total-Count” in a response is returned, with the total number of matching resources so that the client can calculate the next page.
  • Link: This header allows response information to contain a comma separated list of href and rel (relation) information. This header is used in responses, such as for paginated queries. This header allows a way for the API server to tell the API client what HTTP requests the client might want to make in the future. It is like a menu, provided by the server, from which the client is free to choose.

Example

206 Partial Content
Content-Type: application/json
X-Total-Count:9
Link: < /geographicAddressManagement/validate/8313/iterator?offset=3&limit=3>; rel="self",
< /geographicAddressManagement/validate/8313/iterator?offset=0&limit=3>; rel="first",
< /geographicAddressManagement/ validate/8313/iterator?offset=6&limit=3>; rel="next", 
< /geographicAddressManagement/ validate/8313/iterator?offset=0&limit=3>; rel="prev", 
</geographicAddressManagement/ validate/8313/iterator?offset=6&limit=3>; rel="last"
...



...

docs.title: 5. Entity HTTP headers
docs.text:
The following are critical HTTP headers that are about the body of the entity.

  • Content-Length: If in response, this header informs the client about the length of response in decimal number of octets//bytes. If in request, this header informs the MonE API provider about length of the message-body in the request message.
  • Content-Type: This header informs the informs the client about the media type of the resource in response. MonE API(s) supported media type is application/json and charset is utf-8.Default: application/json; charset=utf-8. Please note that charset directive is optional, default encoding being utf-8.
  • Content-Language: This header informs the client about the about the human language the server is expected to send back. Default: en_GB

Example

HTTP/1.1 200 OK 
Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8
Content-Language: en_GB 
Content-Length: 1024
ETag: “customer_24_a11”

docs.title: Methods, Response Codes and Error Representation
docs.text: This section describes the MonE REST API regarding supported operations and response codes.

docs.title: 1. API Methods (http-Methods)
docs.text:
MonE API uses the http-methods as depicted in the following table and detailed in [RFC2616]:

http-METHOD Purpose Description GET Query Entities GET must be used to retrieve a representation of a resource whether be collection or a managed entity resource HEAD GET meta information in HTTP headers only The HEAD method is identical to GET except that the response does NOT contain a message-body. This METHOD is optional and may NOT be supported by some MonE APIs, in which case the very similar result can be achieved by using "fields=none" directive as part of GET requests (See below sections:TODO) POST Create Entity (for a Managed Resource) POST must be used to create a new resource POST Execute an Action on an Entity (for a Task Resource) PUT must be used to execute/trigger an action on a Task Resource identified by its resource URI. PUT Complete Update of an Entity with all its sub parts PUT must be used to completely update a resource identified by its resource URI. Note that any subpart of the resource not provided as part of PUT, means nullifying its value and will be LOST after the update. PATCH Partial Update of an Entity for the provided sub parts PATCH must be used to partially update a resource identified by its resource URI. Note that ONLY provided subpart of the resource will be modified, the others remaining not changed after a PATCH. DELETE Remove an Entity DELETE must be used to delete a resource identified by its resource URI. Note that the back-end API functionality may be marking the entity as DELETED instead of physical removal, still resulting in the same but operationally a more secure effect.

Warning

GET and POST must not be used to tunnel other request methods.

docs.title: 2. HTTP Response/Status Codes Overview
docs.text:
REST APIs use the Status-Line part of an HTTP response message to inform clients of their request’s overarching result. [RFC2616] defines the Status-Line syntax as shown below. Please note that the following is the same whether application layer protocol HTTP/1.1 is used without protocol security or encrypted using TLS.

HTTP Response Status-Line as per [RFC2616] is as the following:

HTTP-Version SP Status-Code SP Reason-Phrase CRLF

where:

  • HTTP-Version: is HTTP protocol version
  • SP: space
  • Status-Code: is HTTP Status Code
  • Reason-Phrase: is the phrase associated with Status-Code, intended to give a short textual description of the Status-Code
  • CRLF: is carriage return followed by line feed

Some example(s) are: 

* HTTP/1.1 200 Success
* HTTP/1.1 206 Partial Response
* HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request

The following table depicts a high-level list of responses codes aligned with standard HTTP conventions, also followed by MonE APIs:

  • 2xx indicate Success
  • 3xx redirection
  • 4xx indicate Client Error(s)
  • 5xx indicate Server Error(s)

docs.title: 3. MonE API Response/Status Codes
docs.text:
Following industry best practice patterns, MonE API response codes whether be success or error, aligns with TMFORUM Open API Guidelines (Ref. [1], Part-1).

Please note that in order to keep the original semantics of [RFC2616] specification serving as the basis for http-REST style API implementations, the "server" term is used in the response code descriptions. With regards to MonE, this means the MonE component providing the relevant API packaged as a container and deployed on container orchestration platform, such as Kubernetes.

The following sections depict status code(s) supported by MonE APIs.

docs.title: 3.1. Success Status Codes:2xx
docs.text: Status Code Reason-Phrase Description 200 OK OK - Used to indicate nonspecific success. Must not be used to communicate errors in the response. 201 Created Created - Used to indicate successful resource creation. Return message SHOULD contain a resource representation and a Location header with the created resource’s URI. 202 Accepted Accepted - Used to indicate successful start of an asynchronous action, indicating that the submitted request has been successfully accepted by the server. 204 No Content in Response / Deleted No Content / Deleted - Used when the response body is intentionally empty indicating that the MonE API provider has fulfilled the request but does not need to return an entity-body, and returned updated meta information only (response with HTTP-headers). In response to DELETE, this status code is used unless otherwise else specified. 206 Partial Content Partial Content – Used in response to GET indicating partial resource returned in response (with pagination).

docs.title: 3.2. Redirection Status Codes:3xx
docs.text: Status Code Reason-Phrase Description 301 Moved Permanently Moved Permanently - Used to relocate resources. The requested resource has been assigned a new permanent URI and any future references to this resource SHOULD use one of the returned URIs. 303 See Other See Other - In HTTP standards, this status code and method exist primarily to allow the output of a POST-activated script to redirect the user agent to a selected resource. In MonE API(s), this may be used to refer the client to a different URI – can be used with a Location header containing the URI of a resource that shows the outcome of an asynchronous task.   304 (not supported, considered for future) Not Modified Not Modified - Used to preserve bandwidth in the case of conditional gets, which requires additional HTTP Request Header directives: If-Modified-Since, If-Unmodified-Since, If-Match, If-None-Match, or If-Range. Simply, if the client has performed a conditional GET request and access is allowed, but the document has not been modified, the server respond with this status code, and the response without message-body. 307 Temporary Redirect Temporary Redirect - Used to tell clients that the requested URI resides temporarily under a different URI and the client should resubmit the request to this temporary URI.

docs.title: 3.3. Client Error Status Codes:4xx
docs.text: Status Code Reason-Phrase Description 400 Bad Request Bad Request - (Syntax Error in Request Body) The request could not be understood by the server due to malformed syntax. The client SHOULD NOT repeat the request without modifications. 401 Unauthorized Unauthorized - Used when there is a problem with the client’s credentials 403 Forbidden Forbidden - The server understood the request, but is refusing to fulfill it. Authorization will not help and the request. For example, a client may be authorized to interact with some, but not all of a REST API’s resources. If the client attempts a resource interaction that is outside of its permitted scope, the REST API responds respond with 403. 404 Not Found Not Found - The server has not found anything matching the Request-URI. No indication is given of whether the condition is temporary or permanent. This error code is used when a client’s provided URI cannot be mapped to a resource URI. 405 Method Not Allowed Method Not Allowed - The method specified in the Request-Line is not allowed for the resource identified by the Request-URI 406 Not Acceptable Not Acceptable - The resource identified by the request is only capable of generating response entities which have content characteristics not acceptable according to the accept headers sent in the request. 409 Conflict Conflict - The request could not be completed due to a conflict with the current state of the resource. This code is only allowed in situations where it is expected that the user might be able to resolve the conflict and resubmit the request. Conflicts are most likely to occur in response to a updated (PUT/PATCH) requests. For example, if versioning were being used and the entity being PUT included changes to a resource which conflict with those made by an earlier (third-party) request, the server might use the 409 response to indicate that it can't complete the request.  410 Gone Gone - The requested resource is no longer available at the server and no forwarding address is known. This condition is expected to be considered permanent. Clients (if keeping remote links) may delete references to the Request-URI. PLease note that if server does not know, or cannot determine, whether or not the condition is permanent, then simply returns status code 404 (Not Found) instead. 411 Length Required The server refuses to accept the request without a defined Content-Length HTTP Header in request. 412 Precondition Failed Not supported, planned for future releases.Precondition Failed - The precondition given in one or more of the request-header fields evaluated to false when it was tested on the server. 413 Request Entity Too Large Request Entity Too Large - The server is refusing to process a request because the request entity is larger than the server is willing or able to process. 414 Request-URI Too Long Request-URI Too Long - The server is refusing to service the request because the Request-URI is longer than the server is willing to interpret 415 Unsupported Media Type Unsupported Media Type - The request entity has a media type which the server or resource does not support. For example, the client uploads an image as image/svg+xml, but the server requires that images use a different format 422 Unprocessable Entity Unprocessable Entity - (Semantic Error in Request Body) The request body contains well-formed (i.e., syntactically correct), but semantically erroneous context (which means neither 415-Unsupported Media Type nor 400-Bad Request applies to this error). 429 Too Many Requests Too Many Requests – SHOULD be used to indicate that the client has sent to many requests in a given amount of time (“rate limiting”). This response code is indirectly supported as a side car capability to MonE component APIs via container platform provided load balancing/throttling capabilities resource, such as nginx/ingress.

docs.title: 3.3. Server Error Status Codes:5xx
docs.text: Status Code Reason-Phrase Description 500 Internal Server Error Internal Server Error – a generic error message, given when an unexpected condition was encountered preventing the server from providing fulfilling the request. 501 Not Implemented Not Implemented - The server does not support the functionality required to fulfill the request. This is the appropriate response when the server does not recognize the request method and is not capable of supporting it for any resource.Usually this implies future availability (e.g., a new feature of a web-service API) 502 Bad Gateway Bad Gateway - The server, may be acting as a gateway, proxy, or broker being dependent on other server(s) APIs (aka required APIs) to fulfill the request. This response code indicates that the server received an invalid response from the other upstream server(s) while attempting fulfill the request. Please also see 504 503 Service Unavailable Service Unavailable - The server is currently unavailable (because it is overloaded or down for maintenance). Generally, this is a temporary state. 504 Gateway Timeout Service Unavailable - The server, while acting as a gateway or proxy, did not receive a timely response from the upstream server(s) while attempting to fulfill the request.

docs.title: 4. Error Representation
docs.text:
MonE APIs adhere to TMFORUM API Guidelines recommendations for the representation of detailed application specific error objects, but also extends the TMFORUM recommended Error Representation with Industry best practices (Google APIs) to include additional informative information in error responses.

The following table depicts the Error Representation in body of the response returned by MonE APIs.

Property Description Mandatory (M) / Optional (O) code Application related code (as defined in the API or from a common list) M reason Text that explains the reason for error. This can be shown to a client user. M message Text that provide more details and corrective actions related to the error. This can be shown to a client user. O status http error code extension like 400-2 O referenceError url pointing to documentation describing the error O @baseType When sub-classing, this defines the super-class. O @schemaLocation A URL to a JSON-Schema file that defines additional attributes and relationships. O @type When sub-classing, this defines the sub-class entity name. O domain Domain of the error, such as:
  • Integration APIs
  • Charging
  • Billing
  • Database
  • In-Memory Cache
  • Message Bus
O source Source component name that raised the error, such as:
  • C-FMF
  • API-ORDER-MGMT
  • MonE_DB
O locationType locationType of the error, such as:
  • request.header, request.parameter, request.body
  • database-sql
  • etc.
O location If available more details on the location of the error. O

The following are some examples:

Example-1

{
  "code": 400,
  "reason": "Bad Request",
  "message": "Invalid sort directive parameters.",
  "domain": "Integration APIs",
  "component": "API-ACCOUNT-MGMT", 
  "locationType": "parameter",
  "location": "sort"
 }
}

Example-2

{
  "code": 401,
  "reason": "Unauthorized",
  "message": "Invalid credentials.",
  "domain": "Integration APIs",
  "component": "API-ACCOUNT-MGMT", 
  "locationType": "parameter",
  "location": "apiKey"
 }
}

docs.title: Monitor Resource Patterns
docs.text:
In the context of asynchronous (ASYNC) processing for the operations as detailed in Managed, Collection Resources Management Patterns and Task Resource Patterns sections, the successful response is "202 Accepted" with a reference to a monitor so that the client can check the completion status of the ASYNC operation. This section details the use of such Monitor resources.

http-GET method on the ASYNC response monitor resource (202 Accepted) is used to query the completion status of a previously submitted POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE request. The following design guidelines apply for this pattern:

  • Content-Type: application/json
  • POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE operations on a monitor resource is NOT defined. Therefore, such an attempt always returns "405 Method Not Allowed".

The following table depicts the critical response codes for this scenario. For details of response codes, please refer to Methods, Response Codes and Error Representation.

Response Codes-Success Response Codes-Error
  • 200 OK
  • 400 Bad Request
  • 404 Not Found
  • 5XX Server Errors

The following example depicts the attributes of a Monitor Resource, where:

  • @type, @SchemaLocation, id, href and name: These fields are the same as per all Managed Entity objects
  • state: The state of monitor resource, such as InProgress, InError, Completed
  • sourceHref: The actual monitored resource to be queried, if the state of the Monitor is Completed
  • request: represents the original asynchronous request, providing http method, header and body information that resulted in creation of this monitor.
  • response: represents the original asynchronous response, providing http method, header and body information.
{
  "@type": "monitor", 
  "@schemaLocation": "https://bss.operator.com/MonE/schemas/Monitor.schema.json", 
  "href": "https://bss.operator.com//MonE/accountManagement/v4/monitor/29",
  "sourceHref": "https://bss.operator.com//MonE/accountManagement/v4/partyAccount/101",
  "id": "14",
  "name": "Monitor-account-29",
  "state": "Completed", 
  "request": {
    "method": "POST", 
    "to": "",
    "header": [
      ...ORIGINAL REQUEST HEADER FROM PREVIOUS SERVICE CALL...
    ]
    "body": {
      ...ORIGINAL REQUEST BODY FROM PREVIOUS SERVICE CALL...
    }
  }
  "response": {
    "statusCode": "202", 
    "header": [
      ...ORIGINAL RESPONSE HEADER FROM PREVIOUS SERVICE CALL...
    ]
    "body": {
      ...ORIGINAL RESPONSE BODY FROM PREVIOUS SERVICE CALL...
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Other Complementary Patterns
docs.text:
This section extends the API Guidelines described on all other sections. The purpose is to highlight the MonE API behavior in more enhanced edge case scenarios, as the following:

  • Extension Patterns: This section details MonE API applied extension principles, such as for extending the basic schema of TMFORUM entities, adding characteristics and/or relationships
  • CRUD Operations on Polymorphic Collections: This section details behavior of CRUD operations on polymorphic collections. Including but not limited to extended types, CRUD operations for Polymorphic Collections and Types, such as query by providing one or more "@type" parameters using the base type or create/update/delete a sub type using the API of the base type
  • Hypermedia Representation: As detailed in API Guidelines sections Response headers and Query Multiple Resources: With Pagination, MonE APIs already utilize HTTP response "Link" attribute, providing information to the API client what HTTP requests the client can make in the future. This section details the enhanced API patterns in which MonE API response body includes links and actions that are available for a given resource, in a given state.
  • Entity Versioning and Lifecycle Management: Especially very critical to Product Lifecycle Management, it is a must to distinguish resources representing entities running with different version numbers and accessible though the same API version. This section provides insights to Entity Versioning patterns utilized by MonE APIs

docs.title: 1.1. Creating a single resource
docs.text:
http-POST method is used for creation of a single resource. The following design guidelines apply for this pattern:

  • Content-Type: application/json
  • Return message contains the full representation of the resource
  • Client can control representation of the resource via attribute selector directive fields=field1,field2, ... In this case, requested fields will be presented. If fields=none, then response contains only id, href and name (also optionally @type, @schemaLocation as per API implementation).
  • For optional and not specified attributes of the resource model, entity is populated by default values as per entity schema specification.

The following table depicts the critical response codes for this scenario. For details of response codes, please refer to Methods, Response Codes and Error Representation.

  • 202 Accepted (if ASYNC)

  • 404 Not Found
  • 405 Method Not Allowed
  • 409 Conflict
  • 5XX Server Errors

docs.title: 1.2. Creating multiple resources
docs.text:
http-PATCH method is used for creation of multiple resources. The following design guidelines apply for this pattern:

  • Content-Type: application/json-patch+json
  • PATCH operation is relative to the container collection for the entity types to be created, where the following directives detail the type of update:
    • “op” is the action to take. For creating multiple resources at a given path, always "add".
    • “path” is a pointer/reference to the field to change.
    • “value” is the value object to add.
  • Return message contains the full representation of the resource
  • Client can control representation of the resource via attribute selector directive fields=field1,field2, ... In this case, requested fields will be presented. If fields=none, then response contains only id, href and name (also optionally @type, @schemaLocation as per API implementation).
  • For optional and not specified attributes of the resource model, entity is populated by default values as per entity schema specification.
  • The HTTP PATCH method is atomic, as per [RFC5789] i.e., all operations MUST be successful otherwise the application of the full PATCH is unsuccessful.

The following table depicts the critical response codes for this scenario. For details of response codes, please refer to Methods, Response Codes and Error Representation.

Response Codes-Success Response Codes-Error
  • 200 OK (if SYNC)
  • 202 Accepted (if ASYNC)
  • 204 No Content
  • 400 Bad Request
  • 404 Not Found
  • 405 Method Not Allowed
  • 409 Conflict
  • 5XX Server Errors

docs.title: 2. Query Resources Patterns
docs.text:
The fundamental concept in MonE RESTful API is the resource with media type "application/json". The following diagram depicts the two possible types of resources in a response to a query: whether a single object, or a collection/array of objects.

Figure-1: Query Response: Resource Models

This section details the query method patterns of resources in the following sections:

  • Querying a single resource
  • Querying multiple/collection resources
  • Querying multiple/collection resources with JSON Path Extension

docs.title: 2.1. Querying a single resource
docs.text:
http-GET method is used for querying of a single resource. The following design guidelines apply for this pattern:

  • GET {apiRoot}/{resourceName}/{resourceID} MUST be used to retrieve the representation of a Managed Resource named resourceID.
  • Return message contains the full representation of the resource
  • Client can control representation of the resource via attribute selector directive fields=field1,field2, ... In this case, requested fields will be presented. If fields=none, then response contains only id, href and name (also optionally @type, @schemaLocation as per API implementation).
  • If resource identified by URI cannot be identified 404 Not Found is returned.

The following table depicts the critical response codes for this scenario. For details of response codes, please refer to Methods, Response Codes and Error Representation.

Response Codes-Success Response Codes-Error
  • 200 OK
  • 400 Bad Request
  • 404 Not Found
  • 405 Method Not Allowed
  • 5XX Server Errors

Example-2

docs.title: 2.2. Querying multiple resources
docs.text:
http-GET method is used for querying of multiple resources. The following design guidelines apply for this pattern:

  • GET {apiRoot}/{resourceName} MUST be used to retrieve the representation of a Collection Resource
  • Return message contains the array of one or more Managed Resource entities that constitute the Collection Resource
  • For query-based pagination, the HTTP header “X-Total-Count” in a response is returned, with the total number of matching resources so that the client can calculate the next page.
    • offset and limit parameters are used to control pagination by the client.
  • If no paging query parameters are specified in the URI then all matching resources are returned to the consumer, considering the default default paging values for offset and limit.
    • If the response can fit a single page, response code returned is 200
    • If the response cannot fit a single page, then the response code returned is 206.
  • In the case of pagination, the responses contain Link HTTP header that allows a way for the server to communicate the client a menu for possible future requests from which the client is free to choose, such as "first", "next", "prev", and "last" page related URLs.
  • Each entity in return message contains the full representation of the resource
  • Client can control representation of the entity resources via attribute selector directive fields=field1,field2, ... In this case, requested fields will be presented. If fields=none, then response contains only id, href and name (also optionally @type, @schemaLocation as per API implementation).
  • If resource identified by URI cannot be identified 404 Not Found is returned.

The following table depicts the critical response codes for this scenario. For details of response codes, please refer to Methods, Response Codes and Error Representation.

Response Codes-Success Response Codes-Error
  • 200 OK
  • 206 Partial Content (returned in case of pagination)
  • 400 Bad Request
  • 404 Not Found
  • 405 Method Not Allowed
  • 5XX Server Errors

docs.title: 2.2.4. Query Multiple Resources: Conditional Collection Filtering
docs.text:
This section describes the TMFORUM open API basic design patterns for conditional attribute filtering with less flexibility. Please note that unless otherwise explicitly specified in section MonE Public APIs Specification, all MonE Public API supports JSONPath based conditional attribute filtering as detailed in next section.

It is possible to have conditional collection items filtering, while issuing query multiple resources. The basic expression is one or a sequence of ANDED attribute assertions to formulate a filtering expression as the following usage patterns:

  • SINGLE CONDITION: GET {apiRoot}/{resourceName}?{attributeName1}={attributeValue1}
  • MULTIPLE CONDITIONs: GET {apiRoot}/{resourceName}?{attributeName1}={attributeValue1}&{attributeName2}={attributeValue2}...

The following table depicts the operators that may be used:

Operator URL Encoded Form Suffix Form Description = %3D%3D .eq equal to ( = ) Return results where the search criteria field is equal to > %3E .gt greater than ( > ) Return results where the search criteria field is strictly greater than ≥ %3E%3D .gte greater than or equal to ( >= ) Return results where the search criteria field is equal to or greater than < %3C .lt less than ( > ) Return results where the search criteria field is strictly less than ≤ %3C%3D .lte less than or equal to ( >= ) Return results where the search criteria field is equal to or less than *= %3D~ .regex Regex expression Note: all regex special characters must be encoded

The following table depicts conditional attribute filtering usage examples. Note that some examples provide both types of usage via Suffix Form or URL encoded form of the operator presented in the table above.

GET /MonE/accountManagement/v4/partyAccount?offset=0&limit=10&state=active;state=suspended ";" is an EXPLICIT OR. Get the first 10 entities of Party Accounts WHERE state=active OR state=suspended. docs.title: 2.3. Querying Multiple Resources with JSON Path Extension
docs.text:
This section describes MonE API JSON Path support for querying multiple resources adhering to TMFORUM open API JSON Path based design patterns for conditional attribute filtering as detailed in (Ref. [1], Part-6). Please note that unless otherwise explicitly specified in section MonE API Catalog & Specs, all MonE API supports JSONPath based conditional attribute filtering as detailed in this section.

Please note that PAGINATION logic and directives are as described in Query Multiple Resources: With Pagination.

http-GET method is used for querying of multiple resources. The following design guidelines apply for this pattern:

  • GET {apiRoot}/{resourceName} MUST be used to retrieve the representation of a Collection Resource
  • Return message contains the array of one or more Managed Resource entities that constitute the Collection Resource
  • For query-based pagination, the HTTP header “X-Total-Count” in a response is returned, with the total number of matching resources so that the client can calculate the next page.
    • offset and limit parameters are used to control pagination by the client.
  • If no paging query parameters are specified in the URI then all matching resources are returned to the consumer, considering the default default paging values for offset and limit.
    • If the response can fit a single page, response code returned is 200
    • If the response cannot fit a single page, then the response code returned is 206.
  • Each entity in return message contains the full representation of the resource
  • Client can control representation of the entity resources via attribute selector directive fields={JSONPath*}. In this case, requested fields as per provided JSONPath will be presented. As a shortcut, if fields=none, then response contains only id, href and name (also optionally @type, @schemaLocation as per API implementation).
  • For conditional collection filtering, filter={JSONPathExpression} query directive is used as described in this section, instead of the pattern as described in previous section Query Multiple Resources: Conditional Collection Filtering.
  • If resource identified by URI cannot be identified 404 Not Found is returned.

The following table depicts the critical response codes for this scenario. For details of response codes, please refer to Methods, Response Codes and Error Representation.

Response Codes-Success Response Codes-Error
  • 200 OK
  • 206 Partial Content (returned in case of pagination)
  • 400 Bad Request
  • 404 Not Found
  • 405 Method Not Allowed
  • 5XX Server Errors

docs.title: 2.3.1. JSONPath Overview
docs.text: The equivalent of XPath for JSON documents is called JSON Path. It is a query-oriented language that allows querying and extraction of subsection(s) of a JSON document.

docs.title: 2.3.1.1. JSONPath Expression & Operators
docs.text:
The following table depicts the JSON Path expression and operators:

Expression & Operator Description $ Root object/element to query. This is how all the path expressions are started. @ The current node being processed - it is used in the input expressions for filter predicates. .<attribute> Child selector - selects the specified property in a parent object using the "dot" (.) notation. ['<attribute>(,'<attribute>')] Child or children selector - selects the specified property or properties in a parent object using the "bracket" ([) notation. Note: This expression SHOULD be used if the attribute contains special characters such as spaces, or begins with a character other than A..Za..z_. .. Recursive descent. It will search for the specified attribute name recursively and it will return an array of all values with the attribute name. It will always return a list, even if only one property is found. * Wildcard selector. It will select all elements (object or array) regardless of their names or indexes. For example, $.relatedEntity[0][*] means all attributes of the first object from the relatedEntity array, and $.relatedEntity[*] means all items of the relatedEntity array. [n] Selects the nth element from an array. Indexes are 0-based. [indexNr, indexNr, ...] Selects array elements with the specified indexes. Returns a list. [start:end][start:] Array slice operator. It will select array elements from the start index and up to, but not including, end index. If the end is omitted, selects all elements from start until the end of the array. Returns a list. [:n] Selects the first n elements of the array. Returns a list. [-n:] Selects the last n elements of the array. Returns a list. [,] Union operator. JSONPath allows alternate names or array indices as a set. [?(expression)] Filter expression. Selects all elements in an object or array that match the specified filter. [(expression)] Script expression. Script expressions can be used instead of explicit property names or indexes. An example is [(@.length-1)] which selects the last item in an array. Here, length refers to the length of the current array rather than a JSON field named length.

Example

JSON Path 

$.channel

RESULT

All the properties of the channel 

{
  "id" : "8774",
  "name" : "Self Service", 
  "@type" : "Channel"
}

Example

JSON Path 

$['id','name','href']

RESULT

Select multiple children from the root element. This operator is very useful in the partial response scenario. 

{
  "id" : "3180",
  "name" : "Compliant over last bill",
  "href" : "https://host:port/troubleTicket/v2/troubleTicket/3180"
}

Example

JSON Path 

$..name

RESULT

Select all the ‘name’ attributes across all the resource structure including sub parts. 

[
  "Compliant over last bill",
  "November Bill", 
  "December Bill", 
  "December Bill", 
  "November Bill ", 
  "Self Service"
]

Example

JSON Path 

$.note[*].author

RESULT

All the authors attribute values from all the elements of the 'note' array. 

[

docs.title: 2.3.1.2. JSONPath Filter Expression Predicates
docs.text:
JSONPath predicate filters are Boolean expressions (true or false) that restrict returned lists of nodes - usually applied to arrays. The filter syntax is: 

[?(expression)]

As detailed in previous section regarding JSONPath operators, the filter syntax is generally used in conjunction with the "@" operator (@ pointier to current item being processed) to create the predicate.

If predicate filter does NOT validate, an empty response is returned.

Example

JSON Path Expression 

statusChange[?(@.status=='Pending')]

RESULT

Retrieve statusChange sub element from ROOT, that has statusChange.status child having 'Pending' value. 

[
  {
    "status" : "Pending",
    "changeReason" : "Need more information from the customer", 
    "changeDate" : "2018-05-01T00:00"
  }
]

Example

JSON Path Expression 

statusChange[?(@.status==$.status)]

RESULT

Retrieve statusChange sub element from ROOT, that has statusChange.status child having $.status (status at ROOT) 'Resolved' value. 

[
  {
    "status" : "Resolved",
    "changeReason" : "Issue has been resolved", 
    "changeDate" : "2018-05-02T00:00"
  }
]

The following table depicts the JSON Path filter expression related operators:

Operator Description == Equal to 1 and '1' are considered equal. String values should be enclosed in single quotes or double-quotes. != Not equal to. > Greater than >= Greater than or Equal to < Less than <= Less than or Equal to =~ Match a JavaScript regular expression. For example, $.statusChange[?(@.status=~/Resol.*?/i)] matches items whose status starts with Resol. ! Negate filter condition. Use to negate a filter: $.attachment[?(!@.size)] matches items that do not have the size property. && Logical AND Used to combine multiple filter expressions: $.attachment[?(@.size==300 && @.sizeUnit=='KB')] || Logical OR Used to combine multiple filter expressions: $.attachment[?(@.size==300 || @.size==500)]

The following are some examples:

Example

JSON Path Expression 

$.attachment[?(@.size==300)]

RESULT 

[
  {
    "description": "Scanned disputed December bill",
    "href" : "http://hostname:port/documentManagement/v2/attachment/44",
    "id" : "44",
    "url" : "http://xxxxx",
    "name" : "December Bill", 
    "size" : 300,
    "sizeUnit" : "KB", 
    "@referredType" : "Attachment"
  }
]

Example

JSON Path Expression 

$.statusChange[?(@.status!='Pending')]

RESULT 

[
  {
    "status" : "InProgress",
    "changeReason": "Working on the issue resolution",
    "changeDate": "2018-05-02T00:00" 
  },
  {
    "status" : "Resolved",
    "changeReason" : "Issue has been resolved", 
    "changeDate" : "2018-05-02T00:00"
  }
]

Example

JSON Path Expression 

$.attachment[?(@.size>300)]

RESULT 

[
  {
      "description": "Scanned disputed November bill",
      "href": "http://hostname:port/documentManagement/v2/attachment/45",
      "id": "45",
      "url": "http://xxxxx",
      "name": "November Bill ",
      "size": 500,
      "sizeUnit": "KB",
      "@referredType": "Attachment"
  }
]

Example

JSON Path Expression 

$.statusChange[?(@.status=~ /Resol.*?/i)]

RESULT 

[
  {
      "status": "Resolved",
      "changeReason": "Issue has been resolved",
      "changeDate": "2018-05-02T00:00"
  }
]

Example

JSON Path Expression 

$.attachment[?(@.size==300 && @.sizeUnit=='KB')]

RESULT 

[
  {
    "description": "Scanned disputed December bill",
    "href" : "http://hostname:port/documentManagement/v2/attachment/44",
    "id" : "44",
    "url" : "http://xxxxx",
    "name" : "December Bill", 
    "size" : 300,
    "sizeUnit" : "KB", 
    "@referredType" : "Attachment"
  }
]

Example

JSON Path Expression 

$.attachment[?(@.size==300 || @.size==500)]

RESULT 

[
  {
      "description": "Scanned disputed December bill",
      "href": "http://hostname:port/documentManagement/v2/attachment/44",
      "id": "44",
      "url": "http://xxxxx",
      "name": "December Bill",
      "size": 300,
      "sizeUnit": "KB",
      "@referredType": "Attachment"
  },
  {
      "description": "Scanned disputed November bill",
      "href": "http://hostname:port/documentManagement/v2/attachment/45",
      "id": "45",
      "url": "http://xxxxx",
      "name": "November Bill ",
      "size": 500,
      "sizeUnit": "KB",
      "@referredType": "Attachment"
  }
]

docs.text:
In order to retrieve a subset of resources, the “filter” selector MUST be used:

GET {apiRoot}/{resourceName}/?filter={JSONPath Expression}

docs.title: 2.3.3. Sorting with JSONPath
docs.text:
To support sorting the sort directive is used as HTTP query parameter. The definition is as the following:

sort=[direction]sort-field, [direction]sort-field,...

where:

  • direction : is optional. Default is "+" indicating ascending. Can be: “-“ | “+”
  • sort-field: The field to sort on, specified as a JSONPath expression

Example

GET /api/troubleTicket?sort=channel.name
Access: application/json

or

GET /api/troubleTicket?sort=attachment[*].name
Access: application/json

or

GET /api/troubleTicket?filter=attachment[?(@.size==300)]&fields==['id','href','name']& sort=attachment[*].name
Access: application/json

docs.title: 2.4. Query Depth and Expand Directives
docs.text:
As for any REST based API, MonE API query responses, return single or a collection of resources in which each resource contain referenced entities. A common use case is to query a resource and “dereference” or “embed” the hyperlinked resource representations. Control of expansion in the hierarchy of referenced objects is controlled via the following two directives:

  • depth: The value of this directive controls the number of depth level subject to expansion in the hierarchy of references.
    • If depth=0, then no expansion, meaning all referenced entities and response is just RootEntity objects which contains only @type, @schemaLocation, id and href.
    • If depth = 1, then the first level of related target entities is expanded. References are replaced with the actual loaded entities with the corresponding level of details.
    • If depth = N it expands reference objects of related entities recursively. The last level contains only the references.
  • expand: It is optional and must be used together with depth. The value of this directive is used to narrow down (filter) expanding of the referenced objects.
    • If expand is not specified, then by default all the paths should be expanded as per specified depth value.
    • If the expand parameter is specified, only those paths should be expanded according to depth parameter.

docs.title: 3.1. Full Update: Replace ALL attributes of a resource
docs.text:
http-PUT method is used for updating all attributes of a resource. The following design guidelines apply for this pattern:

  • Content-Type: application/json
  • http-PUT cannot be used for partial update. One approach to using PUT to facilitate a partial “replace” functionality is to first GET the object, modify it in memory, then to PUT the modified object back.
  • For full update, in the input id, href and read-only and non-nullable attributes MUST be specified explicitly at all times.
  • To empty a resource, call http-PUT on the specific resource with an input that ONLY consists of id and href.
  • For partial updates http-PATCH must be used (please refer to next sections).
  • Return message contains the full representation of the resource.
  • Client can control representation of the resource via attribute selector directive fields (Please refer to Query Resources Patterns for details regarding the usage of this directive in basic and JSONPath modes). In this case, requested fields will be presented. If fields=none, then response contains only id, href and name (also optionally @type, @schemaLocation as per API implementation).

The following table depicts the critical response codes for this scenario. For details of response codes, please refer to Methods, Response Codes and Error Representation.

Response Codes-Success Response Codes-Error
  • 200 OK (if SYNC)
  • 202 Accepted (if ASYNC)
  • 400 Bad Request
  • 404 Not Found
  • 405 Method Not Allowed
  • 409 Conflict
  • 5XX Server Errors

Example-1

Update a resource: change state to suspended

REQUEST 

PUT /MonE/accountManagement/v4/partyAccount/101 
Content-Type: application/json

{

  "@schemaLocation": "https://bss.operator.com/MonE/schemas/SpecialAccount.schema.json", 
  "id": "101",
  "href": "https://bss.operator.com//MonE/accountManagement/v4/partyAccount/101",
  "name": "Travel account",
  "lastModified": "2020-07-04T22:00:00.663Z",
  "state": "suspended",
  "relatedParty": [
    {
      "@referredType": "Organization",
      "id": "4665",
      "href": "https://bss.operator.com/MonE/partyManagement/v4/organization/4665", 
      "name": "John Doe",
      "role": "owner"
    } 
  ]
}

RESPONSE 

200 OK
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "@type": "PartyAccount",
  "@schemaLocation": "https://bss.operator.com/MonE/schemas/SpecialAccount.schema.json", 
  "id": "101",

docs.title: 3.2. Partial Update: Modify Attribute subset a resource
docs.text:
http-PATCH method is used for updating a limited subset of the attributes of an entity as described in [RFC5789] and [RFC7386]. The following design guidelines apply for this pattern:

  • Content-Type: application/json
  • For partial updates, in the input only the to-be-updated fields are provided.
  • Return message contains the full representation of the resource.
  • Client can control representation of the resource via attribute selector directive fields (Please refer to Query Resources Patterns for details regarding the usage of this directive in basic and JSONPath modes). In this case, requested fields will be presented. If fields=none, then response contains only id, href and name (also optionally @type, @schemaLocation as per API implementation).

The following table depicts the critical response codes for this scenario. For details of response codes, please refer to Methods, Response Codes and Error Representation.

Response Codes-Success Response Codes-Error
  • 200 OK (if SYNC)
  • 202 Accepted (if ASYNC)
  • 400 Bad Request
  • 404 Not Found
  • 405 Method Not Allowed
  • 409 Conflict
  • 5XX Server Errors

Example-1

Partial update a resource: change state to suspended

Note that in the input only the updated field(s) need to be provided provided.

REQUEST 

PATCH /MonE/accountManagement/v4/partyAccount/101 
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "state": "suspended"
}

RESPONSE 

200 OK
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "@type": "PartyAccount",
  "@schemaLocation": "https://bss.operator.com/MonE/schemas/SpecialAccount.schema.json", 
  "id": "101",
  "href": "https://bss.operator.com//MonE/accountManagement/v4/partyAccount/101",
  "name": "Travel account",
  "lastModified": "2020-07-04T22:00:00.663Z",
  "state": "suspended",
  "relatedParty": [
    {
      "@referredType": "Organization",
      "id": "4665",
      "href": "https://bss.operator.com/MonE/partyManagement/v4/organization/4665", 
      "name": "John Doe",
      "role": "owner"
    } 
  ]
}

docs.title: 3.3. Partial Update: Modify Lists
docs.text:
http-PATCH method is used for modification of list based (multi-valued) attributes of a resource. The following design guidelines apply for this pattern:

  • Content-Type: application/json-patch+json
  • PATCH operation is relative to the container collection for the entity types to be created, where the following directives detail the type of update:
    • “op” is the action to take. The following operations are supported: "add", "remove", "replace", "copy", "move", "test". Operation names are self-explanatory, except for "test". The "test" operation tests that a value at the target location is equal to a specified value.
    • "from" is OPTIONAL and required in case of "copy" and "move"
    • “path” is a pointer/reference to the field to change, but also utilizes JSONPath. For background information regarding JSONPath and filter selectors, please refer to JSONPath.
    • “value” is the value to use. Not required if "op" is "remove"
  • Return message contains the full representation of the resource.
  • Client can control representation of the resource via attribute selector directive fields (Please refer to Query Resources Patterns for details regarding the usage of this directive in basic and JSONPath modes). In this case, requested fields will be presented. If fields=none, then response contains only id, href and name (also optionally @type, @schemaLocation as per API implementation).
  • For optional and not specified attributes of the resource model, entity is populated by default values as per entity schema specification.
  • The HTTP PATCH method is atomic, as per [RFC5789] i.e., all operations MUST be successful otherwise the application of the full PATCH is unsuccessful.

The following table depicts the critical response codes for this scenario. For details of response codes, please refer to Methods, Response Codes and Error Representation.

Response Codes-Success Response Codes-Error
  • 200 OK (if SYNC)
  • 202 Accepted (if ASYNC)
  • 204 No Content
  • 400 Bad Request
  • 404 Not Found
  • 405 Method Not Allowed
  • 409 Conflict
  • 5XX Server Errors

ASSUME THE FOLLOWING AS THE CURRENT (BEFORE UPDATE) STATUS OF THE RESOURCE FOR THE FOLLOWING EXAMPLES 

{
  "@type": "PartyAccount",
  "@schemaLocation": "https://bss.operator.com/MonE/schemas/SpecialAccount.schema.json", 
  "id": "101",
  "href": "https://bss.operator.com//MonE/accountManagement/v4/partyAccount/101",
  "name": "Travel account",
  "lastModified": "2020-07-04T22:00:00.663Z",
  "state": "active",
  "relatedParty": [
    {
      "@referredType": "Organization",
      "id": "5555",
      "href": "https://bss.operator.com/MonE/partyManagement/v4/organization/5555", 
      "name": "John Doe",
      "role": "owner"
    } 
  ]
}

Example-1

Add two relatedParties to partyAccount/101

REQUEST 

PATCH /MonE/accountManagement/v4/partyAccount/101
Content-Type: application/json-patch+json
[
  {
    "op": "add",
    "path": "/relatedParty",
    "value": [
        {
          "@referredType": "Organization",
          "id": "6666",
          "href": "https://bss.operator.com/MonE/partyManagement/v4/organization/6666", 
          "name": "Jane Doe",
          "role": "owner"
        },

docs.title: 3.4. Partial Update: Modify Lists with JSON Patch Query and JSONPath filters
docs.text:
JSON Patch Query [RFC6902] is a format for expressing a sequence of operations to apply to a target JSON document for use with the HTTP PATCH method. Thus, JSON Patch Query extends JSON Patch in order to handle partial updates of elements within an array without previous knowledge of the order in which the impacted elements are located within the array. Using JSON Patch Query blended with JSONPath filter selector capabilities, there is no need to refer to indexes within the array but use the contents of the different parameters defining the structure as the reference to identify each individual element within the array.

http-PATCH method is used for modification of list based (multi-valued) attributes of a resource via JSON Patch Query pattern. The following design guidelines apply for this pattern:

  • Content-Type: application/json-patch-query+json
  • PATCH operation is relative to the container collection for the entity types to be created, where the following directives detail the type of update:
    • “op” is the action to take. The following operations are supported: "add", "remove", "replace", "copy", "move", "test". Operation names are self-explanatory, except for "test". The "test" operation tests that a value at the target location is equal to a specified value.
    • "from" is OPTIONAL and required in case of "copy" and "move"
    • “path” is a pointer/reference to the field to change, but also utilizes JSONPath. For background information regarding JSONPath and filter selectors, please refer to JSONPath.
    • “value” is the value to use. Not required if "op" is "remove"
  • Return message contains the full representation of the resource.
  • Client can control representation of the resource via attribute selector directive fields (Please refer to Query Resources Patterns for details regarding the usage of this directive in basic and JSONPath modes). In this case, requested fields will be presented. If fields=none, then response contains only id, href and name (also optionally @type, @schemaLocation as per API implementation).
  • For optional and not specified attributes of the resource model, entity is populated by default values as per entity schema specification.
  • The HTTP PATCH method is atomic, as per [RFC5789] i.e., all operations MUST be successful otherwise the application of the full PATCH is unsuccessful.

The following table depicts the critical response codes for this scenario. For details of response codes, please refer to Methods, Response Codes and Error Representation.

Response Codes-Success Response Codes-Error
  • 200 OK (if SYNC)
  • 202 Accepted (if ASYNC)
  • 204 No Content
  • 400 Bad Request
  • 404 Not Found
  • 405 Method Not Allowed
  • 409 Conflict
  • 5XX Server Errors

docs.title: 4. Delete Resources Patterns
docs.text:
http-DELETE method is used for deletion/removal of a resource. The following design guidelines apply for this pattern:

  • Content-Type: application/json (for response). A Delete operation does NOT accept a request payload.

The following table depicts the critical response codes for this scenario. For details of response codes, please refer to Methods, Response Codes and Error Representation.

Response Codes-Success Response Codes-Error
  • 200 OK (if SYNC and if the action has been enacted and the response message includes a representation describing the status)
  • 202 Accepted (if ASYNC )
  • 204 No Content (if SYNC and if the action has been enacted and no further information is to be supplied)
  • 400 Bad Request
  • 404 Not Found
  • 405 Method Not Allowed
  • 409 Conflict
  • 5XX Server Errors

Example-1

Delete a resource

REQUEST 

DELETE /MonE/accountManagement/v4/partyAccount/101

RESPONSE 

204 No Content

docs.title: 1. Encryption
docs.text: MonE APIs support Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS) for secure communication over the IP network subsystem. In HTTPS, the HTTP/1.1 protocol is encrypted using TLS (Transport Layer Security) cryptographic protocol (or formerly SSL-Secure Sockets Layer). The principal motivations for HTTPS are validating the authenticity of the accessed website, and protection of the privacy and integrity of the exchanged data while in transit. It protects against man-in-the-middle attacks, and the bidirectional encryption of communications between a client and server protects the communications against eavesdropping and tampering. In practice, this provides a reasonable assurance that one is communicating with the intended website without interference from attackers.

docs.title: 2. API Key Authentication
docs.text:
MonE supports API Key based authentication used together with HTTPS for public APIs. An API key is a unique identifier token/secret that a client provides when making MonE Public API calls. The API Key is created as part of a MonE platform tenant/customer onboarding process. Each MonE Platform tenant/customer must create at least one API key credential and API Key must be provided in all MonE supported HTTTP request types (GET, POST, PUT, ...).

Important

Restricting API Keys adds security to your application by ensuring only authorized requests are made with your API Key as well as associating an external client request with a specific MonE Platform tenant/customer. Restrict your key to prevent unauthorized use in production.

API Key may be communicated either in URL-Path or in HTTP-Header while issuing MonE API calls, as detailed in the following sub sections.

docs.title: 2.1. API Key in URL-Path
docs.text:
While issuing MonE API calls, replace YOUR_API_KEY with your API key.

...
GET /MonE/accountManagement/v4/billingAccount?apiKey=YOUR_API_KEY 
...
PUT /MonE/accountManagement/v4/billingAccount/101?apiKey=YOUR_API_KEY 
...

docs.title: 2.2. API Key in HTTP Header
docs.text:
While issuing MonE API calls, provide YOUR_API_KEY in HTTP Request Header as the following:

  • Authorization: Must contain "typespacecredentials" to authenticate a user agent (client) with the API Key, where;

  • type: Indicates authentication method type. Must be "Bearer"

  • credentials: Indicates BASE64 encoded form of API Key. As an example for API Key "AIzaSyC1jYXX90_h5F0L1zafJzAm_RQGMaxqACA" , BASE64(API Key) yields "QUl6YVN5QzFqWVhYOTBfaDVGMEwxemFmSnpBbV9SUUdNYXhxQUNB"

Example

...
Authorization: Bearer QUl6YVN5QzFqWVhYOTBfaDVGMEwxemFmSnpBbV9SUUdNYXhxQUNB=
...

docs.title: 3. Open Authorization (OAuth)
docs.text:
MonE supports OAuth 2.0 based authorization as part of tenant/customer onboarding process to MonE platform. Once a tenant/customer is onboarded, API Key Credential must be created by the customer to be able to issue MonE API calls as detailed in above 2. API Key Authentication.

OAuth 2.0 (Open Authorization) as defined in [RFC6749] is an open standard authorization framework for token-based authorization on the internet. OAuth separates the authentication provider from the resource. The authorization server issues access tokens which are used to access the protected resource. This allows consumption of the API without sharing credentials with the API provider. OAuth 2.0 is implemented in various ways using flows. The most common flow for machine-to-machine interfaces is the Client Credentials flow (Ref. [1], Part-1), as also supported by MonE APIs. Below is a sequence diagram illustrating the Client Credentials flow.

Figure-1: MonE API: OAuth Flow

OAuth authorization lets client access protected resources by presenting the obtained access token to the resource server (MonE API). Simply, when used, OAuth uses standard HTTP Request Header Authorization to be provided by the calling client as the following:

  • Authorization: Must contain "typespacecredentials" to authenticate a user agent (client) with the MonE API server, where;

  • type: Indicates authentication method type. Must be "Bearer"

  • credentials: Bearer token type as defined in [RFC6750]

Example

...
Authorization: Bearer mF_9.B5f-4.1JqM
...

docs.title: URL Path Structure and API Style
docs.text: This section details the naming and JSON style guidelines supported by MonE APIs.

docs.title: 1. API URL Path Structure and Versioning
docs.text:
The following pattern constitutes the MonE service endpoint URL Path structure including versioning, in which [optional] imply the optional parts.

{protocol}://{serverRoot}[:port]/{apiRoot}/{VERSION}/{resourceName}/[{resourceID}]

Example

The following is an example WITHOUT the [optional] parts.

https://bss.operator.com/MonE/customerManagement/v4/customer where;

  • customer denotes Resource Name

The following is an example INCLUDING the [optional] parts.

https://bss.operator.com:8080/MonE/customerManagement/v4/customer/42 where;

  • customer denotes Resource Name
  • 42 denotes the resource Identifier

API Versioning adheres to the following principles:

  • MonE APIs state version with “v” following the API Name, e.g.: APIName/v1/resource.
  • Schema associated with has its version number aligned with that of the API.
  • The version number has major, minor and revision numbers. E.g. v1.0.0
  • Only the major version number is held in the URI. E.g customerManagement/v1/customer.
  • Any change that causes backward incompatibility results in an increment of the version number:
  • Major changes are such as an existing sub part structure change or element type changes resulting in the client logic to break.
  • Minor backward compatible changes are such as; new optional elements added, cardinality of attributes from mandatory to optional or from lower to greater etc. do NOT impact backward compatibility and does not result in major number increment.

docs.title: 2. API Resource Archetypes
docs.text:
MonE REST APIs resource archetypes align each resource to just one of these:

  • Collection Resource – set or collection of resources. A resource with no identifier represents the Collection Resource, such as https://bss.operator.com/MonE/customerManagement/v4/customer
  • Managed Resource – an object instance (that may represent a persisted database record etc.). A resource with identifier represents Managed Resource. Its representation includes: fields with values and links to related resources. Can have child resources, of different resource types. Client can create, query, update and delete resources. Example: https://bss.operator.com/MonE/customerManagement/v4/customer/42
  • Task Resource – resources that are executable functions – with associated input and output parameters. Necessary where the required action cannot be mapped to standard CRUD methods. Tasks play the role of Controllers e.g. ProductOfferingQualification, ServiceQualification. Example: https://bss.operator.com/MonE/productOfferingQualification/v4/productOfferingQualification

docs.title: 3.   Resource Name Guidelines
docs.text:
Resource names must conform to the following guidelines:

  • Resource names should be meaningful names with defined semantics, derived from TMF Open APIs and Information Framework Resource name MUST NOT expose technical or implementation details. For example, resourceSpecification, NOT resourceSpec
  • Resource names must be camel case, ascii strings.
  • Each Collection Resource or Managed Resource name must be a NOUN, except for Tasks which must be a verb.
  • Collection Resource names MUST NOT have a specific notation, such as "Collection" postfix or plural form. For example, API/ticket represents the Ticket Collection and GET API/ticket retrieves all the items from the Ticket Collection (i.e. all the resources of type Ticket contained within the application). So forms like API/ticketCollection or API/tickets MUST NOT be used.

docs.title: 4.1.    Definitions
docs.text:
The readers familiar with JSON syntax can skip this section.

JSON syntax is derived from JavaScript object notation syntax:

  • Data is in name/value pairs
  • Data is separated by commas
  • Curly braces hold objects
  • Square brackets hold arrays

For the purposes of this style guide, the definitions of the following terms are important:

  • resource field (aka property) - a name/value pair inside a JSON object.
  • field name (aka property name) - the name (or key) portion of the property.
  • field value (aka property value) - the value portion of the property.

Example

The following is a simple JSON object specifying values of field/property names: name and surname 

{
  "name": "John",
  "lastName": "Doe"
}

Example

The following is a more complex conceptualJSON object specifying a conceptual resourceX that is related to two items 

{
  "id": "123",
  "href": "https://bss.operator.com:8080/MonE/xyzManagement/v4/resourceX/123",
  "description": "resourceX",
  "isActive": true,
  "lastUpdate": "2020-07-01T06:11:00.281Z",
  "lifecycleStatus": "retired",
  "name": "resourceX_123",
  "version": "v1",
  "attachment": [
    {
      "id": "54",
      "attachmentType": "file",
      "mimeType": "application/json",
      "name": "file54.json",
      "url": "ftp://ftp.myCatalog.com/itemCatalog/54"
    },
    {
      "id": "55",
      "attachmentType": "file",
      "mimeType": "application/json",
      "name": "file55.json",
      "url": "ftp://ftp.myCatalog.com/itemCatalog/55"
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: 4.2.    Resource Field (Property) Naming Guidelines
docs.text:
Property names must conform to the following guidelines:

  • Property names should be meaningful names with defined semantics.
  • Property names must be camel case, ascii strings.
  • The first character can be a letter, an (at sign) "@", (an underscore) "_" or (a dollar sign) "$".
  • Subsequent characters can be a letter, a digit, an underscore, or a dollar sign.

docs.title: 4.3.    Resource Field (Property) Value Guidelines
docs.text:
Field values must contain one of:

  • a string
  • a number
  • a JSON object
  • an array

  • a boolean

  • Property values conform the JSON spec, which details exactly what type of data is allowed in a property value. This includes Unicode booleans, numbers, strings, objects, arrays, and null.

  • JavaScript expressions are not allowed.
  • MonE APIs choose the data type most appropriate for a particular property (numbers to represent numbers, etc.). Javascript's number type encompasses all floating-point numbers, which is a broad designation. Numbers refer to JavaScript's number type, while integer will refer to integers.

Good example ( // are for comments only and NOT part of the JSON): 

{
  "canCowsFly": null,   // null
  "isThisOK": false,    // boolean
  "yourID": 42,         // number-integer
  "actualValue": 79.82, // number-float  
  "name": "John",       // string
  "moreData": {         // object
      "dataVal1": 12,
      "dataVal2": 22
  },
  "things": [
      "thing1", "thing2"
  ]           
}

Bad example: 

{
  "aVariableName": aVariableName,         // Bad - JavaScript identifier
  "functionFoo": function() { return 1; }    // Bad - JavaScript expressions not allowed
}

docs.title: 4.4. Reserved Resource Field (Property) Names
docs.text:
The words below are reserved by the JavaScript language and cannot be referred to using dot notation. The list represents best knowledge of keywords at this time; the list may change or vary based on your specific execution environment. Referenced from the ECMAScript Language Specification 5th Edition, below are the reserved keywords that shall be avoided to be used as a property name:

abstract

debugger default delete do double
else enum export extends

goto return

let long
